Subsubsection Text: Rule 15c6-1 of the U.S. Exchange Act, trades in the secondary market generally are required to settle in two business days unless the parties to any such trade expressly agree otherwise. Accordingly, purchasers who wish to trade the Notes on the date of this Offering Memorandum or the next         business days will be required, by virtue of the fact that the Notes initially will settle T+  , to specify an alternative settlement cycle at the time of any such trade to prevent a failed settlement. Subsubsection Text: This Offering Memorandum is being provided (1) to a limited number of investors that we reasonably believe to be QIBs under Rule 144A under the U.S. Securities Act for informational use solely in connection with their consideration of the purchase of the Notes and (2) to investors that are non-U.S. persons outside of the United States pursuant to offshore transactions complying with Rule 903 or Rule 904 of Regulation S under the U.S. Securities Act. The Notes are subject to restrictions on transferability and resale and may not be transferred or resold except as permitted under the U.S. Securities Act and the applicable state securities laws, including pursuant to registration or exemption therefrom. You should be aware that you may be required to bear the financial risks of this investment for an indefinite period of time. See “Plan of Distribution” and “Transfer Restrictions” for a description of certain further restrictions on offers and sales of the Notes and distribution of this Offering Memorandum.

HOWEVER, THERE IS NO ASSURANCE THAT THE STABILIZING MANAGERS (OR ANY PERSON ACTING ON BEHALF OF THE STABILIZING MANAGERS) WILL UNDERTAKE STABILIZATION ACTION. ANY STABILIZATION ACTION MAY BEGIN ON OR AFTER THE DATE ON WHICH ADEQUATE PUBLIC DISCLOSURE OF THE FINAL TERMS OF THE OFFER OF THE NOTES IS MADE AND, IF BEGUN, MAY BE ENDED AT ANY TIME, BUT IT MUST END NO LATER THAN THE EARLIER OF 30 DAYS AFTER THE ISSUE DATE OF THE NOTES AND 60 DAYS AFTER THE DATE OF THE ALLOTMENT OF THE NOTES. ANY STABILIZATION ACTION OR OVER ALLOTMENT MUST BE CONDUCTED BY THE STABILIZING MANAGERS (OR PERSONS ACTING ON BEHALF OF THE STABILIZING MANAGERS) IN ACCORDANCE WITH ALL APPLICABLE LAWS AND RULES. FOR A DESCRIPTION OF THESE ACTIVITIES, SEE “PLAN OF DISTRIBUTION.” iii -----

Section Title: NOTICE TO EUROPEAN ECONOMIC AREA INVESTORS
Subsubsection Text: The Notes are not intended to be offered, sold or otherwise made available to and should not be offered, sold or otherwise made available to any retail investor in the European Economic Area (the “EEA”). For these purposes, a retail investor means a person who is one (or more) of: (i) a retail client as defined in point (11) of Article 4(1) of Directive 2014/65/EU (as amended, “MiFID II”); (ii) a customer within the meaning of Directive (EU) 2016/97 (as amended, the “Insurance Distribution Directive”), where that customer would not qualify as a professional client as defined in point (10) of Article 4(1) of MiFID II or (iii) not a “qualified investor” as defined in Regulation (EU) 2017/1129, as amended (the “EU Prospectus Regulation”). Consequently no key information document required by Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 (as amended, the “PRIIPs Regulation”) for offering or selling the Notes or otherwise making them available to retail investors in the EEA has been prepared and therefore offering or selling the Notes or otherwise making them available to any retail investor in the EEA may be unlawful under the PRIIPs Regulation. This Offering Memorandum has been prepared on the basis that any offer of Notes in any member state of the EEA will be made pursuant to an exemption under the Prospectus Regulation from the iv ----- requirement to publish a prospectus for offers of Notes. This Offering Memorandum is not a prospectus for the purposes of the Prospectus Regulation. Solely for the purposes of each manufacturer’s product approval process in the EEA, the target market assessment in respect of the Notes has led to the conclusion that: (i) the target market for the Notes is eligible counterparties and professional clients only, each as defined in MiFID II; and (ii) all channels for distribution of the Notes to eligible counterparties and professional clients are appropriate. Any person subsequently offering, selling or recommending the Notes (an “EEA distributor”) should take into consideration each manufacturer’s target market assessment; however, an EEA distributor subject to MiFID II is responsible for undertaking its own target market assessment in respect of the Notes (by either adopting or refining each manufacturer’s target market assessment) and determining appropriate distribution channels.

The Notes are not intended to be offered, sold or otherwise made available to and should not be offered, sold or otherwise made available to any retail investor in the United Kingdom (the “UK”). For these purposes, a retail investor means a person who is one (or more) of: (i) a retail client, as defined in point (8) of Article 2 of Regulation (EU) No 2017/565 as it forms part of domestic law by virtue of the European Union (Withdrawal) Act 2018 (“EUWA”); or (ii) a customer within the meaning of the provisions of the Financial Services and Markets Act 2000 (as amended, “FSMA”) and any rules or regulations made under the FSMA to implement the Insurance Distribution Directive, where that customer would not qualify as a professional client, as defined in point (8) of Article 2(1) of Regulation (EU) No 600/2014 as it forms part of domestic law by virtue of the EUWA. Consequently no key information document required by Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 as it forms part of domestic law by virtue of the EUWA (the “UK PRIIPs Regulation”) for offering or selling the Notes or otherwise making them available to retail investors in the UK has been prepared and therefore offering or selling the Notes or otherwise making them available to any retail investor in the UK may be unlawful under the UK PRIIPs Regulation. In the UK, this Offering Memorandum and any other material in relation to the Notes described in this Offering Memorandum are being distributed only to, and are directed only at, persons who are “qualified _investors” (as defined in the UK Prospectus Regulation) who are (i) persons having professional experience in_ matters relating to investments falling within Article 19(5) of the Financial Services and Markets Act 2000 (Financial Promotion) Order 2005 (as amended, the “Order”), (ii) high net worth entities falling within Article 49(2)(a) to (d) of the Order, or (iii) persons to whom it would otherwise be lawful to distribute them, all such persons together being referred to as “Relevant Persons.” In the UK, the Notes are only available to, and any invitation, offer or agreement to subscribe, purchase or otherwise acquire such Notes will be engaged in only with, Relevant Persons. This Offering Memorandum and its contents are confidential and should not be distributed, published or reproduced (in whole or in part) or disclosed by any recipients to any other person in the UK. Any person in the UK that is not a Relevant Person should not act or rely on this Offering Memorandum or its contents. The Notes are not being offered to the public in the UK. Solely for the purposes of the manufacturer’s product approval process in the UK, the target market assessment in respect of the Notes has led to the conclusion that: (i) the target market for the Notes is only eligible counterparties, as defined in the FCA Handbook Conduct of Business Sourcebook (“COBS”), and professional clients, as defined in Regulation (EU) No 600/2014 as it forms part of UK domestic law by virtue of the European Union (Withdrawal) Act 2018 (“UK MiFIR”); and (ii) all channels for distribution of the Notes to eligible counterparties and professional clients are appropriate. Any person subsequently offering, selling or recommending the Notes (a “UK distributor”) should take into consideration the manufacturer’s target market assessment; however, a UK distributor subject to the FCA Handbook Product Intervention and Product Governance Sourcebook (the “UK MiFIR Product Governance Rules”) is responsible for undertaking its own target market assessment in respect of the Notes (by either adopting or refining the manufacturer’s target market assessment) and determining appropriate distribution channels.

The Notes may only be offered or sold to the public in the Republic of Ireland or underwritten or placed in conformity with the provisions of: (i) the Prospectus Regulation, European Union (Prospectus) Regulations 2019 and any rules and guidance issued by the Central Bank of Ireland (the “Central Bank”) under Section 1363 of the Companies Act 2014 (as amended, the “Irish **Companies Act”); (ii) the European Union (Markets in Financial Instruments) Regulations 2017 (as amended, the “MiFID Regulations”), including, without limitation, Regulation 5 (Requirement for authorization (and certain provisions concerning multilateral trading facilities and v ----- organized trading facilities)), any codes of conduct made under the MiFID Regulations, and the provisions of the Investor Compensation Act 1998 (as amended) and (iii) the Irish Companies Act, the Central Bank Acts 1942 to 2018 (as amended) and any codes of conduct rules made under Section 117(1) of the Central Bank Act 1989 (as amended) and (iv) the Market Abuse Regulation (EU 596/2014) (as amended), the European Union (Market Abuse) Regulations 2016 of Ireland and any rules and guidance issued by the Central Bank under Section 1370 of the Irish Companies Act.

This Offering Memorandum does not constitute an offer of or an invitation to purchase or subscribe for the Notes in the Commonwealth of Australia or any of its states or territories (“Australia”), and the Notes may not be offered, sold or delivered in or to any resident of Australia except in accordance with applicable law. Neither this Offering Memorandum, nor any other prospectus or disclosure document (as defined in the Australian Corporations Act) in relation to the Notes or the Notes Guarantees has been, or will be, lodged with the Australian Securities and Investments Commission (“ASIC”) or the Australian Securities Exchange operated by ASX Limited (ABN 98 008 624 691) (“ASX”). Each Initial Purchaser has represented and agreed, or will be required to represent and agree, that it (a) has not offered or invited applications, and will not offer or invite applications, for the issue, sale or purchase of any Notes in Australia (including an offer or invitation which is received by a person in Australia) and (b) has not distributed or published, and will not distribute or publish, this Offering Memorandum or any other offering material or advertisement relating to any Notes or Notes Guarantees in Australia, unless in each case: (i) the aggregate consideration payable on acceptance of the offer or invitation by each offeree or invitee is at least A$500,000 (or the equivalent in another currency, in either case disregarding moneys lent by the person making the offer or the invitation or its associates) or the offer or invitation otherwise does not require disclosure to investors in accordance with Part 6D.2 or 7.9 of the Australian Corporations Act; (ii) the offer, invitation or distribution is not made to a person who is a “retail client” within the meaning of section 761G or 761GA of the Australian Corporations Act; (iii) the offer, invitation or distribution complies with all applicable Australian laws, regulations and directives relating to the offer, invitation, sale and resale of the Notes; and (iv) such action does not require any document to be lodged with ASIC or the ASX. In connection with this Offering, the Initial Purchasers are not acting for anyone other than the Issuer and will not be responsible to anyone other than the Issuer for providing the protections afforded to its clients nor for providing advice in relation to this Offering. THIS OFFERING MEMORANDUM CONTAINS IMPORTANT INFORMATION WHICH YOU SHOULD READ BEFORE YOU MAKE ANY DECISION WITH RESPECT TO AN INVESTMENT IN THE NOTES.

This Offering Memorandum includes forward-looking statements within the meaning of the securities laws of certain applicable jurisdictions. These forward-looking statements include, but are not limited to, all statements other than statements of historical facts contained in this Offering Memorandum, including, without limitation, those regarding our intentions, beliefs or current expectations concerning, among other things, our future financial conditions and performance, results of operations and liquidity; our strategy, plans, objectives, prospects, growth, goals and targets; future developments in the markets in which we participate or are seeking to participate; and anticipated regulatory changes in the industry in which we operate. These forward-looking statements can be identified by the use of forward-looking terminology, including the terms “outlook,” “believe(s),”expect(s),” “potential,” “continue(s),” “may,” “will,” “should,” “could,” “would,” “seek(s),” “predict(s),” “intend(s),” “trends,” “plan(s),” “estimate(s),” “anticipates,” “projection,” “goal,” “target,” “aspire,” “will likely result” and other words and terms of similar meaning or the negative versions of such words or other comparable words of a future or forward-looking nature. vi ----- By their nature, forward-looking statements involve known and unknown risks, uncertainties and other factors because they relate to events and depend on circumstances that may or may not occur in the future. We caution you that forward-looking statements are not guarantees of future performance and that our actual financial condition, results of operations and cash flows, and the development of the industry in which we operate, may differ materially from (and be more negative than) those made in, or suggested by, the forward-looking statements contained in this Offering Memorandum. In addition, even if our financial condition, results of operations and cash flows, and the development of the industry in which we operate, are consistent with the forward-looking statements contained in this Offering Memorandum, those results or developments may not be indicative of results or developments in subsequent periods. Factors that could cause such differences in actual results include: ###  economic downturns and political and market conditions beyond our control, including inflation and a reduction in consumer discretionary spending; - competitive pressures given the international nature of competition in online betting and gaming; - failure to retain existing customers for our betting and gaming offerings or to add new customers, or customers could decrease their level of engagement with our betting and gaming offerings in general; - failure to develop successful product offerings or to pursue additional product offerings, or failure to make the right investment decisions in our product offerings and technology; - the dependence of certain of our products on maintaining liquidity; - risks that uncertainty as to the legality of online betting and gaming or adverse public sentiment towards online betting and gaming may deter third-party suppliers from dealing with us; - failure to attract, retain and motivate key or the loss of key personnel; - risks that we may be unable to build, maintain and enhance our brands, or that events may occur that damage our reputation and brands ; - risks that ongoing ability to market to our customers in certain jurisdictions may be adversely affected; ###  the possibility that we may need additional capital and that such capital may not be available to us or available on terms acceptable to us; - future acquisitions, divestitures or other strategic transactions or alliances are subject to domestic and foreign regulatory requirements, and we may face difficulties integrating, separating and managing these businesses; - risks related to our potentially prioritizing customer growth and engagement and the customer experience over short-term financial results; - exposure to trading, liability management and pricing risk as a result of our participation in the sports betting industry; - the success of present and future sports betting and gaming product offerings’ dependence on a variety of factors that are not completely controlled by us; - failure of our operational efforts to expand into new markets, particularly the U.S.; ###  risks related to our contractual and strategic relationships with third parties; - risks relating to the dependence of certain aspects of our businesses on the live broadcasting and scheduling of major sporting events; ###  global economic conditions and geopolitical events, including the ongoing military action between Russia and Ukraine and the military tensions between Israel and Hamas; - work stoppages and other labor problems; vii ----- - difficulties in protecting our intellectual property and other intellectual property-related risks; - risks related to our use of artificial intelligence, machine learning and similar technologies; - risks related to potential security breaches, unauthorized access to or disclosure of our data or customer data, or other cyber incidents; - risks relating to governmental investigations, inquiries, taxation, regulatory actions and litigation; - our dependence on payment processors and international multi-currency transfer systems; - risks relating to exposure to foreign exchange rates; and - risks associated with our financial profile the Notes, the Notes Guarantees, the Collateral and our structure. The foregoing factors and others described under “Risk Factors” should not be construed as exhaustive. Moreover, new risk factors emerge from time to time, and it is not possible for us to predict all such factors. Due to such uncertainties and risks, readers are cautioned not to place undue reliance on such forward-looking statements, which speak only as at the date hereof. We disclose important factors that could cause our actual results to differ materially from our expectations in “Risk Factors” and “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results _of Operations.” Other sections of this Offering Memorandum describe additional factors that could adversely_ affect our business, financial condition or results of operations. Moreover, we operate in a very competitive and rapidly changing environment. New risk factors emerge from time to time and it is not possible for us to predict all such risk factors. We cannot assess the impact of all risk factors on our business or the extent to which any factor, or combination of factors, may cause actual results to differ materially from those contained in any forward-looking statements. Given these risks and uncertainties, you should not place undue reliance on forward-looking statements as a prediction of actual results. Any forward-looking statements are only made as at the date of this Offering Memorandum and, except as required by law or the rules and regulations of any stock exchange on which the Notes are listed, we undertake no obligation to publicly update or publicly revise any forward-looking statement, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise. All subsequent written and oral forward-looking statements attributable to us or to persons acting on our behalf are expressly qualified in their entirety by the cautionary statements referred to above and contained elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum, including those set forth under “Risk _Factors.”_ viii -----

Section Title: PRESENTATION OF FINANCIAL AND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: The Issuer is a wholly owned indirect subsidiary of the Company. The Company is the reporting company of our Group where the Group’s financial information is consolidated. Accordingly, references to the “Group,” “we,” “our,” and “us,” in the context of the financial statements or other financial information presented in this Offering Memorandum, relate to the Company and its consolidated subsidiaries. In connection with our U.S. Listing (as defined herein), effective as of January 29, 2024, we began reporting our historical financial information in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles in the United States (“U.S. GAAP”) and, as a result, changed our reporting currency from pound sterling to U.S. dollar. Accordingly, in this Offering Memorandum, we present the Group’s audited consolidated financial statements as of December 31, 2022 and 2023 and for the years ended December 31, 2021, 2022 and 2023 prepared in accordance with U.S. GAAP. The audited consolidated financial statements included herein do not constitute statutory financial statements for the purposes of the Irish Companies Act, nor do they constitute audited financial statements for the purposes of the Irish Transparency (Directive 2004/109/EC) Regulations 2007. Unless otherwise indicated, the financial information presented in this Offering Memorandum as of December 31, 2022 and 2023 and for the years ended December 31, 2021, December 31, 2022 and December 31, 2023 has been extracted from the Group’s audited consolidated financial statements as of December 31, 2022 and 2023 and for the years ended December 31, 2021, 2022 and 2023, included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum and prepared in accordance with U.S. GAAP. We report our financial results in accordance with U.S. GAAP; however, management believes that certain non-GAAP measures provide useful supplemental information that enables a better comparison of our performance across periods. These include certain operating measures such as AMPs. These also include certain financial measures such as EBITDA, EBITDA Margin, Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA Margin, Further Adjusted EBITDA, Further Adjusted EBITDA Margin, Segment Further Adjusted EBITDA, Segment Further Adjusted EBITDA Margin, Group Ex-US Adjusted EBITDA, Group Ex-US Adjusted EBITDA Margin, Group Ex-US Further Adjusted EBITDA, Group Ex-US Further Adjusted EBITDA Margin, Adjusted Free Cash Flow, Sportsbook Net Revenue Margin and Stakes. The primary non-GAAP financial measures presented in this Offering Memorandum are defined below: - “EBITDA” is defined as net loss before income taxes, interest expense, net and depreciation and amortization; - “EBITDA Margin” is defined as EBITDA divided by revenue for the relevant period; - “Adjusted EBITDA” is defined as EBITDA before other (expense)/income, net, transaction fees and associated costs, restructuring and integration costs, legal settlements/(loss contingencies), gaming tax expenses and impairment; - “Adjusted EBITDA Margin” is defined as Adjusted EBITDA divided by revenue for the relevant period; - “Further Adjusted EBITDA” defined as Adjusted EBITDA excluding share-based compensation charge; - “Further Adjusted EBITDA Margin” is defined as Further Adjusted EBITDA divided by revenue for the relevant period; - “Segment Further Adjusted EBITDA” is defined as segment Adjusted EBITDA, which is our segment measure of profit or loss excluding share-based compensation charge; - “Segment Further Adjusted EBITDA Margin” is defined as Segment Further Adjusted EBITDA as a percentage of revenue; - “Group Ex-US Adjusted EBITDA” is defined as Group Adjusted EBITDA excluding US Segment Adjusted EBITDA; - “Group Ex-US Further Adjusted EBITDA” is defined as Group Ex-US Adjusted EBITDA excluding share-based compensation charge; ix ----- - **Group Ex-US Adjusted EBITDA Margin” is defined as Group Ex-US Adjusted EBITDA as a percentage of revenue; - “Group Ex-US Further Adjusted EBITDA Margin” is defined as Group Ex-US Further Adjusted EBITDA as a percentage of revenue; - “Adjusted Free Cash Flow” is defined as net cash provided by operating activities _excluding changes in operating assets and liabilities related to player deposits, investment and player deposit liabilities, cash paid for transaction fees and associated costs, restructuring fees and integration costs, legal settlement/loss contingencies and includes the cash impact of purchases of property and equipment, purchases of intangible assets and capitalized software; - “Net Debt” is defined as total debt, excluding premiums, discounts, and deferred financing expense, and the effect of foreign exchange that is economically hedged as a result of our cross-currency interest rate swaps reflecting the net cash outflow on maturity less cash and cash equivalents. - “Sportsbook Net Revenue Margin” is defined as revenue from our sportsbook operations divided by Stakes for the period; and - “Stakes” is defined as the total amount our players wagered in sportsbook during the period. We present these non-GAAP measures in this Offering Memorandum because we believe that they provide useful information regarding the Company’s ability to service and incur indebtedness and our management uses them as a measure of evaluating our operating performance. These non-GAAP measures are not measurements of operating performance under U.S. GAAP and should not be considered a substitute for operating income, net income, cash flows from operating activities or other profit and loss account or statement of cash flows information, or as a measure of profitability or liquidity, and do not necessarily indicate whether cash flow will be sufficient or available for cash requirements. Therefore, the non-GAAP measures presented in this Offering Memorandum should be viewed as supplementary to our consolidated financial statements included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum and may not be indicative of our historical operating results nor are they meant to be predictive of potential future results. Because all companies do not calculate such measures identically, the presentation may not be comparable to similarly entitled measures of other companies and you are cautioned not to place undue reliance on such financial information. To properly and prudently evaluate our business, we encourage you to review the consolidated financial statements included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum, and not rely on a single financial measure to evaluate our business. We also strongly urge you to review the reconciliations between our most directly comparable financial measures calculated in accordance with U.S. GAAP measures and our non-GAAP measures set forth in “Summary—Summary Financial Information.” These non-GAAP measures have further limitations as analytical tools. Some of these limitations are: - they do not reflect cash expenditures or future requirements for capital expenditure or contractual commitments; - they do not reflect the interest expense or cash requirements necessary to service interest or principal payments on debt; - they do not reflect any cash income taxes the Group may be required to pay; - they are not adjusted for all non-cash income or expense items that are reflected in the Group’s statements of cash flows; - although depreciation and amortization are non-cash charges, the assets being depreciated and amortized will often have to be replaced in the future, and these measures do not reflect any cash requirements for such replacements; - the further adjustments made in calculating Adjusted EBITDA and Further Adjusted EBITDA are those that management consider not to be representative of the underlying operations of the Group and therefore are subjective in nature; and - other companies in the industry may calculate these measures differently than the Group does, limiting their usefulness as comparative measures. x ----- For a discussion of our financial information, see “Summary—Summary Financial Information,” “Selected Historical Consolidated Financial Information,” “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial _Conditions and Results of Operations” and the consolidated financial statements included elsewhere in this_ Offering Memorandum. We present in this Offering Memorandum certain as adjusted financial data which is based on our consolidated financial information as adjusted to give effect to the Transactions, as if the Transactions had occurred on December 31, 2023 (in the case of consolidated balance sheet information), or January 1, 2023 (in the case of consolidated statement of comprehensive income information), including the application of proceeds from the offering of the Notes as set forth under “Use of Proceeds.” The as adjusted financial data has not been prepared in accordance with the requirements of Regulation S-X of the U.S. Securities Act or other SEC requirements, the Prospectus Regulation or any generally accepted accounting standards. Neither the assumptions underlying the related adjustments nor the resulting as adjusted financial data have been audited or reviewed in accordance with any generally accepted auditing standards. Certain amounts and percentages set out in this Offering Memorandum, including financial information presented in billions, millions or thousands and percentages describing market shares, have been rounded. Accordingly, in certain instances, the sum of the numbers in a column of a table may not exactly equal the total figure for that column. Percentages and amounts reflecting changes over time periods relating to financial and other information set out in “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of _Operations” are calculated using the unrounded numerical data in the financial statements or the tabular_ presentation of other information contained in this Offering Memorandum, as applicable, and not using the numerical data in the narrative description thereof. The financial information included in this Offering Memorandum is not intended to comply with the applicable accounting requirements of the U.S. Securities Act and the related rules and regulations of the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (the “SEC”) which would apply if the Notes were being registered with the SEC.

In this Offering Memorandum, reference is made to information regarding the Group’s business and the markets in which it operates and competes. The market information and certain economic and industry information and forecasts used in this Offering Memorandum were obtained from publications by independent industry sources, including H2 Gambling Capital, and publicly available information that we believe to be reliable. In addition to the foregoing, certain information regarding markets, market size, market share, market position, growth rates and other industry information pertaining to us contained in this Offering Memorandum were based on estimates prepared by management based on certain assumptions and management’s knowledge of the industry in which the Group operates. Industry publications and forecasts generally state that the information they contain has been obtained from sources believed to be reliable, but that the accuracy and completeness of such information is not guaranteed. Management has not independently verified such data and cannot guarantee their accuracy or completeness. In some cases, there is no readily available external information (whether from trade associations, government bodies or other organizations) to validate market-related analyses and estimates, requiring us to rely on the Group’s own internally developed estimates regarding the Group’s position in the industry, the Group’s market share and the market shares of various industry participants based on management’s experience, management’s own investigation of market conditions and management’s review of industry publications, including information made available to the public by the Group’s competitors. None of the Group or the Initial Purchasers can assure you of the accuracy and completeness of, or take responsibility for, such data. Similarly, while management believes its internal estimates to be reasonable, these estimates have not been verified by any independent sources and none of the Group or the Initial Purchasers can assure you as to their accuracy or the accuracy of the underlying assumptions used to estimate such data. The Group’s estimates involve risks and uncertainties and are subject to change based on various factors.

We own or have rights to trademarks and service marks that we use in conjunction with the operation of our business, many of which are registered under applicable intellectual property laws. Solely for convenience, trademarks and trade names referred to in this Offering Memorandum may appear without the ©, ® and ™ symbols, but such references are not intended to indicate, in any way, that we will not assert, to the fullest extent xi ----- under applicable law, our rights or the rights of the applicable licensor to these trademarks and trade names. Other trademarks and tradenames appearing in this Offering Memorandum are the property of their respective holders. We do not intend our use or display of other companies’ trade names, trademarks or service marks to imply a relationship with, or endorsement or sponsorship of us by, any other companies. xii -----

Flutter is the world’s leading online sports betting and iGaming operator with 12.3 million Average Monthly Players (“AMPs”) and $11.8 billion of revenue globally for the year ended December 31, 2023. Our Group consists of a diverse portfolio of leading recreational brands and products with a broad global reach and expansive market share, with 76.0% of our revenue for the year ended December 31, 2023 generated within geographies in which we occupy a number-one position. Across key regulated markets, we hold multiple top-three positions, including number one in the United States for the year ended December 31, 2023, the UK and Ireland for the year ended December 31, 2023 and Australia for the year ended December 31, 2023. Our 23,053 employees across 23 countries operate some of the world’s most innovative, diverse and distinctive online gaming and sports betting brands such as FanDuel, Sky Betting & Gaming, Sportsbet, PokerStars, Paddy Power, Sisal, tombola, MaxBet, Betfair, TVG, Junglee Games and Adjarabet. Flutter has been operating since 1988 and is headquartered in Dublin, Ireland. We operate a divisional management and operating structure across our geographic markets. Each division has a talented and empowered management team, which is responsible for maintaining the momentum and growth in our respective geographic markets. Our divisions are: (i) the United States (“U.S.”), (ii) the UK and Ireland (“UKI”), (iii) Australia and (iv) International. In our UKI division, we hold the leading market position in online gaming and sports betting by net gaming revenue, in the year ended December 31, 2023, and our brands include some of the most popular online gaming and sports betting brands, such as Sky Betting & Gaming, Paddy Power (in which we have both an online and retail offering, including 576 retail shops), Betfair and tombola. In our Australia division, our Sportsbet brand is the market leader in online sports betting, representing an estimated 45% of the online market share in Australia based on gross gaming revenue from online betting and gaming for the year ended December 31, 2023. Our U.S. division includes FanDuel, which is the online sportsbook market leader for the year ended December 31, 2023, currently available in 22 U.S. states, and our iGaming offering, available in five U.S. states. We expect our presence in the United States to increase as additional states legalize online gambling. Our International division operates in over 100 countries and includes the global brands of PokerStars and Betfair, as well as local brands such as Adjarabet and Junglee Games. For the year ended December 31, 2023, 90.1% of our revenue was generated from our online businesses. As of March 26, 2024, our online operations are complemented by our 1,165 retail shops in Armenia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Georgia, Italy, Ireland, Montenegro, North Macedonia, Serbia, the United Kingdom and the United States. Our iGaming products are provided across our online business in many, but not all, jurisdictions in which we offer our sports services.

Subsubsection Title: We are well positioned to capitalize on growth in the global online betting and gaming market, which has a significant runway for future growth, with the United States providing the most exciting opportunity today
Subsubsection Text: The global online betting and gaming market has significant potential for future growth, with more U.S. states expected to regulate online betting and gaming in the coming years. The United States is our 1 ----- most significant market opportunity. FanDuel has continued to see positive legislative momentum, resulting in its online sportsbook being available in 20 U.S. states (Vermont and North Carolina were added in the fiscal quarter ended March 31, 2024) and iGaming being available in five U.S. states as of the last twelve months ended November 30, 2023, representing 45.0% of the U.S. population and 11.5% of the U.S. population, respectively. We expect the total addressable market (“TAM”) for the United States to be greater than $40 billion by 2030 as a result of (i) the maturation of states with existing sports betting and gaming and (ii) the expansion of legalized sports betting and gaming to cover approximately 80% and 25% of the U.S. population, respectively. Our U.S. division saw its market share reach 37%, including an online sportsbook market share based on gross gaming revenue from online sportsbook of 43.2% for the three months ended December 31, 2023, or 53.4% based on net gaming revenue (based on data received from reporting states only). This leading market position was driven by efficient customer acquisition and retention, high-quality products and effective execution of our strategies, and it has enabled us to fully capitalize on our significant opportunity in the United States, as evidenced by our delivery of a positive US Adjusted EBITDA ($65 million) as well as positive US Further Adjusted EBITDA ($167 million) for the year ended December 31, 2023. Outside of the United States, we estimate that the total betting and gaming market was worth $384 billion in 2023, with 30% of this market occurring online. We also estimate that, of the $339 billion TAM outside of the United States, the United Kingdom, Ireland and Australia, $172 billion occurred in regulating or regulated markets, representing a significant opportunity for further growth internationally. We believe our scale and market leading positions in our online betting and gaming markets will enable us to (i) proactively prepare for new market openings and capture and consolidate market share, (ii) continue to benefit from the shift from in person to online betting and gaming and (iii) operate a resilient business model which we believe has allowed us to continue growing through regulatory changes.

Subsubsection Title: We are a global leader and scale operator in online gaming and sports betting with a diversified portfolio of leading brands
Subsubsection Text: We are a leading global online gaming and sports betting operator with 12.3 million AMPs and $11.8 billion of revenue globally, which is 2.5x the revenue of our next largest peer, for the year ended December 31, 2023. We believe our scale provides us with a key advantage over competitors and has contributed to leading positions in our key markets. We held a leading 37% market share (including an online sportsbook market share of 43.2% and an iGaming market share of 25.7%) in the United States for the three months ended December 31, 2023, while our U.S. division revenue grew 40.7% between December 31, 2022 and December 31, 2023. Our leading UKI division had an online market share of 30% (including a sportsbook market share of 41% and an iGaming market share of 23%), based on net gaming revenue from online sportsbook and gaming, for the year ended December 31, 2023. In Australia, Sportsbet enjoyed a leading position, holding an estimated online market share of 45% based on gross gaming revenue from online sports betting and gaming in the year ended December 31, 2023. Throughout our International division, our brands held a range of top-three positions across various geographic markets for the year ended December 31, 2023. Our leading brands, which are among the most recognizable in their markets, include: FanDuel, Sky Betting & Gaming, Sportsbet, PokerStars, Paddy Power, Sisal, tombola, MaxBet, Betfair, TVG, Junglee Games and Adjarabet. The acquisition of Sisal in August 2022 has further improved our broad and geographically diverse offering, increasing our exposure in Italy, which is Europe’s largest regulated gaming market. Additionally, the acquisition of MaxBet in January 2024 added a local hero brand to our portfolio in Serbia, a fast growing regulated market. We believe the diversified nature of our brand portfolio, product mix and geographic footprint has historically delivered a resilient business model and positions us well to capitalize on future growth opportunities. 2 -----

Subsubsection Title: Access to global sector expertise, including an experienced management team focused on delivering our refreshed, a compelling three pillar strategy, and proprietary technology platforms and capabilities drive distinct competitive advantages
Subsubsection Text: Our brands have access to the operating scale of a leader across product, technology, people and capital. We believe that the availability of this company-wide expertise, as and when our brands need it, provides us with a distinctive set of advantages. We devote substantial resources to delivering the best products to our customers. We devote significant capital expenditures in developing and maintaining our proprietary technology as well as to the employment of approximately 7,000 technologists, including approximately 3,200 software engineers, around the Group to which our brands have access. The benefits of our multi-decade investment are available to all our brands, ensuring we are driving market trends and strengthening our compelling customer proposition across the Group, while delivering the benefits of our global scale across each of our local brands. We believe that the market-leading pricing and risk management capabilities underpinning our sportsbook product innovations for each of our sportsbook businesses showcase the benefits of our investment in technology. For example, we first launched the “Same Game Multi” product in Australia and subsequently launched it in other markets around the globe, including as “Same Game Parlay” in the United States. We believe that our investment in technology underlies our competitive advantage in gaming as well. Our four in-house studios provide access to proprietary gaming content which is delivered across the Group to our gaming brands. We have also successfully utilized innovation in our UKI business to drive player engagement, including daily prize mechanics such as Sky Betting & Gaming’s “Prize Machine” and Paddy Power’s “Wonder Wheel.” These innovations have helped to drive gaming momentum, and we have deployed these successes in our other businesses as well, as demonstrated by the launch of the PokerStars “Spin of the Day” mechanic in 2022 and FanDuel’s Reward Machine in 2023. We share access to people and talent across our Group, ensuring our businesses utilize the sector expertise we have built over decades across our diverse portfolio of brands and products. We are led by an experienced, entrepreneurial management team committed to realizing our Group strategy. Our management team is highly qualified and has a track record of navigating regulatory changes while continuing to grow our business. Our management team has demonstrated success with integrating mergers and acquisitions into the existing Group and in realizing synergies created by these acquisitions. The numerous significant mergers and acquisitions that our management team has led us through in our recent history include the acquisitions of Sisal, tombola, MaxBet, Adjarabet and Junglee.

Subsubsection Title: We have a track record of setting and delivering the right strategic priorities
Subsubsection Text: We believe that we have identified the right strategic priorities through our Group strategy and that continued progress on our strategy will continue to deliver sustainable revenue growth along with scale and leadership benefits which will improve profitability and cash flow generation. For example, by setting a clearly defined strategy for success in the United States and effectively executing that strategy, we have developed a profitable business model with revenue generated by existing players funding the cost of player acquisitions and operating expenses, leading to a US Adjusted EBITDA of $65 million and US Further Adjusted EBITDA of $167 million for the year ended December 31, 2023. The Group outside of the U.S. division experienced revenue, Adjusted EBITDA and Further Adjusted EBITDA growth. Revenue outside the United States grew 16%, Group Ex-US Adjusted EBITDA grew 8.5% and Group Ex-US Further Adjusted EBITDA grew 10% year over year between December 31, 2022 and 2023, driven by the acquisition of Sisal, strong AMP growth, enhanced product and generosity initiatives. This was partly offset by lower Adjusted EBITDA and Further Adjusted EBITDA in Australia due to COVID-19 spend reversion, a softer racing market in Australia, and the annualized impact of increased point of consumption tax rate in 2022. Adjusted EBITDA and Further Adjusted EBITDA growth over the same period was also driven by the “Consolidate and Invest” markets within our International division where we aim to build and maintain our leadership positions (including Italy, Spain, Georgia, Armenia, Brazil, India, and Turkey), where revenue grew 14% and Sisal online revenue grew 20% on a pro 3 ----- forma basis to include the Sisal acquisition as if Sisal had been acquired as of January 1, 2022. Group ExUS Adjusted EBITDA Margin and Group Ex-US Further Adjusted EBITDA Margin decreased by 1.7 and 1.4 percentage points, respectively, year over year between December 31, 2022 and 2023, primarily driven by the Australian trends noted above. We also believe that our financial profile showcases a commitment to a disciplined financial policy that is supported by a cash-generative model that we believe to be highly attractive. For the year ended December 31, 2023, we generated $937 million net cash provided by operating activities (2022: $1,163 million) and $938 million of Adjusted Free Cash Flow, 1.6 times our Adjusted Free Cash Flow generated in the year ended December 31, 2022 as a result of strong EBITDA growth, positive working capital movements and, low capital intensity. Our U.S. business generated positive Adjusted EBITDA and Further Adjusted EBITDA in the year ended December 31, 2023, and we believe the ongoing deleveraging impact of the growing U.S. business positions us well to achieve our medium-term leverage goals.

Subsubsection Title: We are focused on driving sustainable long-term success
Subsubsection Text: In February 2022, we launched our “Positive Impact Plan.” Using our global scale combined with local focus, this new Group-wide sustainability strategy builds on the progress we have already made across our three key focus areas – our customers, our colleagues and our communities – and also includes our efforts to reduce our environmental footprint. Devised and driven by our employees, our Positive Impact Plan creates a consistent global approach that aligns with our corporate strategy and gives our diverse portfolio of brands better access to the insights, skills and capabilities of the wider Group in order to develop and deliver local initiatives that create maximum impact. The plan focuses on three key areas of sustainability for the future, with clear long-term goals to: - Help customers Play Well: our goal is to increase the proportion of our online customers that use at least one of our safer gambling tools. As of December 31, 2023, 44.9% of our active online customers were already utilizing our safer gambling tools, increasing from 40.8% as of December 31, 2022. - Empower colleagues to Work Better: Our goal is for our teams to be representative of the places in which we live and work, through a comprehensive diversity and inclusion strategy. As of December 31, 2023, 35.7% of leadership roles at Flutter were held by women. - Work with communities to Do More: our goal is to improve the lives of millions of people through various community support initiatives by using the power of sport and play, the skills of our colleagues and the reach of our brands. While we are actively focused on our three key focus areas, we also recognize the important role we play as a large, multi-national operator to be an industry leader in promoting environmental responsibility. In support of our commitment to reducing our environmental footprint, our Positive Impact Plan also sets environmental goals that include following our roadmap to achieving our net zero ambitions via science-based carbon targets, developing and implementing a global e-waste policy across our divisions and suppliers in the near term and aiming to move all of our energy tariffs, where possible, to renewable energy tariffs over the medium term. We also proactively embrace regulation of our sector, as we recognize such regulation underpins sustainable revenue growth.
We believe that we benefit from the following key strengths that differentiate us from our competitors.

Subsubsection Title: Invest to win in the United States
Subsubsection Text: By building on our sustainable competitive advantages to extend our leadership position in new states and states where we have an existing presence, we believe we are well positioned to act quickly and bolster our leadership in this important market. The first part of our U.S. strategy is to extend our number one position in online sportsbook. Since the repeal of the Professional and Amateur Sports Protection Act (“PASPA”) and the associated start of gambling market liberalization in the United States in 2018, FanDuel has generally been the number one brand in the U.S. market. FanDuel finished the year ended December 31, 2023 with a 43% online sports betting market share, while generating $4.4 billion in revenue for the year ended December 31, 2023. We believe that we will be able to continue to deliver leadership in the U.S. market through the _FanDuel Advantage where we believe that FanDuel is (i) able to acquire players efficiently, (ii) retain players for longer and (iii) earn higher average revenue per player. The second component of our U.S. investment strategy is to utilize our portfolio of assets and our expertise to grow our gaming proposition. We intend to do this by increasing our focus on gaming direct customers, improving the breadth of our product offering in our FanDuel Casino brand and developing engaging promotional tools.

Subsubsection Title: Grow our leading market positions in core markets
Subsubsection Text: Our core markets remain a crucial pillar of our strategy. By retaining our challenger mindset and continuing to invest in our brand and product propositions, we intend to extend our leadership position and grow our recreational customer base efficiently, leveraging local scale to unlock benefits across these markets. Our Australia and UKI divisions experienced strong recreational customer growth in the year ended December 31, 2023, with AMPs having increased a combined 9% between the two divisions compared to the year ended December 31, 2022. We believe our scale will position us well to invest in our brand and product leadership to continue to deliver best-in-class experiences to our customers. To build upon the momentum we generated from previous market leading product innovations, such as our Sportsbet “Same Game Multi” and daily prize mechanics, such as the Sky Vegas “Prize Machine,” we intend to continue to invest in our products in order to deliver the next generation of product advantages. In the year ended December 31, 2023, our scale and product leadership enabled us to maintain our gold medal positions in our core markets, including a 2 percentage point increase in our UKI market share. For example, our UKI division launched “Live Casino” products and Sky Bet’s “AccaFreeze” during the year ended December 31, 2023. In addition, the acquisition of Sisal in August 2022 has provided us with another gold medal position in Italy, one of the world’s largest regulated markets. As we further integrate our brands in the UK and Ireland, we intend to utilize our local and global scale to continue delivering growth through regulatory changes and realize further cost efficiencies based on the sharing of our global resources and capabilities.

Subsubsection Title: Build on our network and invest for leadership positions across international markets
Subsubsection Text: As a global operator, we understand that our strength lies in combining our global scale with local knowledge. By utilizing these leadership advantages, we intend to extend our leadership positions internationally through building and buying businesses that occupy top-three market positions in regulated markets to maximize the network benefits of our products. We have identified four key areas to bolster our framework for future growth: - By deploying our resources and capital, we intend to consolidate our number-one positions in our largest markets, such as in Italy following our acquisition of Sisal, thereby driving profitable growth. - We intend to invest for leadership in fast-growing markets, such as India, Brazil, and Turkey, where we have been generating strong returns on incremental product and marketing investments. - We intend to optimize our returns from other regulated markets, mainly across Europe, based on our current market position or market growth outlook. 5 ----- - Maintain our presence in other regulated and regulating markets which are generating positive contribution and/or provide future growth optionality. - We also intend replicate the success we achieved with the acquisitions of Adjarabet and Junglee Games by identifying acquisition targets that are a strategic fit for us, establishing additional leadership positions among the top-three operators in attractive, fast-growing markets where organic growth is slower or more challenging to achieve. The acquisition of MaxBet, which holds a podium position in the attractive Serbian market, in January 2024, is the most recent example of this strategy in action. In the year ended December 31, 2023, we continued to improve our revenue mix across both products and geographies. For the year ended December 31, 2023, the International division contributed 23.9% of our revenue (December 31, 2022: 22%).

Our scale and geographic footprint have been transformed since we set our initial pillared strategy in 2018. With successful progression and delivery against these goals, we refreshed our strategic priorities in 2022 to ensure they reflect our evolving approach. We believe the newly refreshed strategy will deliver and defend leading market positions for our existing businesses as well as ensure the continued cultivation of an innovative mindset that will allow us to capitalize on future opportunities. These new priorities also recognize the role we play as a responsible global leader in our industry by placing sustainability at the heart of everything we do. Our commitment to sustainability is demonstrated by our Positive Impact Plan, discussed above. 4 -----

Flutter Treasury DAC is a designated activity company incorporated under the laws of Ireland, with its registered office at Belfield Office Park, Beech Hill Road, Clonskeagh, Dublin 4, D04 V972, Ireland, and registered with the Companies Registration Office of Ireland, with the registration number 748909.

On January 29, 2024, the Company completed (i) the additional listing of its ordinary shares in the United States on the New York Stock Exchange (“NYSE”) and (ii) the cancellation of the secondary listing of the Company’s ordinary shares on Euronext Dublin. The Company retains its premium listing on the London Stock Exchange (“LSE”) and its ordinary shares continue to trade on the main market of the LSE. Among other benefits, the Company believes that listing on the NYSE will unlock long-term strategic and capital market benefits by enhancing the Group’s profile in the United States, better allowing it to recruit and retain key U.S. talent, providing the Group access to deeper capital markets and new U.S. domestic investors, providing greater overall liquidity in the Company’s shares and providing the optionality to pursue a primary listing in the U.S., which is a criterion for access to important U.S. indices. The board of directors of the Company (the “Board”) believes that the NYSE is now the optimal location for the Company’s primary listing of its shares, and that the transition should be made as soon as practicable. This proposal will be put to shareholders as a special resolution at the 2024 Annual General Meeting of the Company’s shareholders on May 1, 2024. Subject to shareholder approval, the transition is expected to become effective late in the second or early in the third quarter of 2024. Following transition, the Board intends to retain the Company’s UK listing as a secondary listing.

On September 27, 2023, we executed an agreement to acquire an initial 51% stake in MaxBet, Serbia’s second-largest omni-channel sports betting and gaming operator for a cash consideration of €141 million ($153 million), on a debt and cash free basis. Under the terms of the agreement we have the opportunity to acquire the remaining 49% in 2029. We believe that MaxBet will provide us the opportunity to expand into the Balkans region with a strong podium brand. The transaction closed on January 9, 2024.

On March 14, 2024, the Company and the TLB Borrowers entered into the Assumption Agreement, which amends the Credit Agreement. After giving effect to the Assumption Agreement, the aggregate principal amount of our Term Loan B Facility outstanding under the Credit Agreement increased by $514 million (the “Incremental TLB

Subsubsection Title: Appointment of Phil Bishop as Group Chief Operating Officer
Subsubsection Text: Phil Bishop was appointed as Group Chief Operating Officer, effective March 1, 2024, following the announcement of Jonathan Hill’s resignation, which was effective March 31, 2024. Mr. Bishop was previously the Chief People Officer of the Company from July 2022 and led the development of our global people strategy and plan. Lisa Sewell will follow Mr. Bishop as Chief People Officer. See “Management— _The Company—Executive Committee.”_

Subsection Title: Facility”), which amount is fungible with the borrowings under the Term Loan B Facility outstanding under
Subsubsection Text: the Credit Agreement prior to the date of the Assumption Agreement. The Incremental TLB Facility (i) refinances the 2028 USD Term Loan B Facility, (ii) matures on November 30, 2030, (iii) bears interest, at 6 ----- the TLB Borrowers’ option, at a per annum rate equal to a margin over either (x) ABR (provided that in no event shall such ABR rate with respect to the Incremental TLB Facility be less than 1.50% per annum) plus an applicable margin equal to 1.25% (or 1.00% upon the applicable leverage ratio decreasing to 2.55:1 or below) or (y) Term SOFR (provided that in no event shall such Adjusted Term SOFR rate with respect to the Incremental TLB Facility be less than 0.50%) plus an applicable margin equal to 2.25% (or 2.00% upon the applicable leverage ratio decreasing to 2.55:1 or below) and (iv) requires scheduled amortization payments in quarterly amounts equal to 0.25% of the original principal amount of the Incremental TLB Facility, payable quarterly, with the balance to be paid at maturity on November 30, 2030.

For the period ended March 17, 2024, our total revenue increased by 23.4% compared to the period ended March 17, 2023. Total revenue for our U.S. segment grew by 55.6% between the period ended March 17, 2024 and the period ended March 17, 2023, reflecting strong Sportsbook and iGaming revenue growth of 63.7% and 50.3%, respectively. Total revenue for our UKI segment grew by 17.3% in the same period due to improved product proposition and strong iGaming revenue. Australia revenue declined 8.8% for the period ended March 17, 2024. This was due to racing market softness and was partly offset by favorable sports results. Total revenue for our International segment grew by 3.0% for the period ended March 17, 2024. Our Sportsbook Net Revenue Margin grew by 9.7% in the period ended March 17, 2024.

_The diagram below illustrates, in simplified form, the Group’s current corporate and financing structure after giving effect to the Transactions. The diagram does not include all entities in the Group or the external shareholding in some of the Group entities. See also “Use of Proceeds,” “Capitalization,” “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements” and “Description of the Notes.”_ (1) The equity shares of the Company are admitted to the premium listing segment of the Official List of the Financial Conduct Authority and trade on the Main Market for listed securities of the London Stock Exchange. Following the U.S. Listing, the equity shares of the Company are also admitted to a secondary listing on the NYSE. See “—Recent Developments—U.S. _Listing.” As of December 31, 2023, the shareholding of the Company was widely distributed and the Company is not aware of_ any person who, directly or indirectly, exercises, or could exercise control over the Company. For details of shareholders with major interests in the equity shares of the Company, as notified to the Company, see “Shareholders.” (2) The entities in the Restricted Group are subject to the covenants in the Credit Agreement and the Indenture. As of the Issue Date, all of the Company’s subsidiaries are restricted subsidiaries. (3) On November 24, 2023, we entered into the Credit Agreement, which provides for (i) a multicurrency Revolving Credit Facility of £1,000 million made available to the TLA/RCF Borrowers, (ii) a EUR Term Loan A Facility to the TLA/RCF Borrowers with €380 million of aggregate commitments, priced at EURIBOR plus a margin of 1.75% and a EURIBOR floor of 0%, (iii) a GBP Term Loan A Facility to the TLA/RCF Borrowers with £1,034 million of aggregate commitments, priced at compounded SONIA plus a margin of 1.75% and a compounded SONIA floor of 0%, (iv) a USD Term Loan A Facility to the TLA/RCF Borrowers with $166 million of aggregate commitments, priced at Term SOFR plus 0.10% plus a margin of 1.75% and a Term SOFR floor of 0% and (v) a USD Term Loan B Facility to the TLB Borrowers with $3,400 million of aggregate commitments, priced at Term SOFR plus a margin of 2.25% and a Term SOFR floor of 0.50%. On March 14, 2024, we entered into the Assumption Agreement, which provides for the Incremental TLB Facility in the amount of $514 million. Repayment of the TLA/RCF Facilities is due on November 30, 2028. There is no amortization on the TLA/RCF Facilities. The Term Loan B Facility will require scheduled quarterly amortization payments in an annual amount equal to 1.0% of the original principal amount of the Term Loan B Facility, with repayment of the balance to be due November 30, 2030. The Credit Facilities are, or will be, guaranteed by the Issuer and the Guarantors and, subject to the Intercreditor Agreement and the Agreed Security 1 ----- Principles, are, or will be, secured, as applicable, by first-ranking security interests over the Collateral. See also “Capitalization” and “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements.” (4) The Notes will be senior secured obligations of the Issuer and will rank pari passu in right of payment with all other existing and future senior debt of the Issuer, including the Credit Facilities and certain hedging obligations. Subject to the Agreed Security Principles, the Notes will be guaranteed on a senior secured basis by the Company and the other Guarantors, which are also guarantors of the Credit Facilities on or about the Issue Date. The validity and enforceability of the Notes Guarantees and the liability of each Guarantor will be subject to the limitations described in “Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of _Guarantees and Security and Certain Insolvency Law Considerations.” As of and for the year ended December 31, 2023, the_ Issuer and the Guarantors represented 73% of the Group’s revenue, 128% of the Group’s EBITDA and 99% of the Group’s total assets, excluding intercompany eliminations. Pursuant to the Security Documents, and subject to the Intercreditor Agreement, the Agreed Security Principles, Permitted Liens and certain perfection requirements, as soon as reasonably practicable after the Issue Date, and in any event within 25 business days of the Issue Date, the Notes and the Notes Guarantees will be secured on a first-ranking basis by security interests granted over the Collateral that also secure, or will secure, as applicable, the obligations of the Issuer and the Guarantors under the Credit Facilities. The security interests in the Collateral may be released under certain circumstances. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to our Financial Profile, the Notes, the Notes _Guarantees and the Collateral,” “Description of Other Indebtedness—Intercreditor Agreement” and “Description of the Notes—Security.”_ (5) As at December 31, 2023, after giving effect to the Transactions, the Company’s subsidiaries that will not guarantee the Notes would not have had any indebtedness outstanding. (6) The Issuer is a direct subsidiary of TSE Holdings Limited. 2 -----

See “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements— _Intercreditor Agreement.”_ Security: ..................................** Pursuant to the Security Documents, as soon as reasonably practicable after the Issue Date, and in any event within 25 business days of the Issue Date, the Issuer and certain of the Guarantors will, subject to the Intercreditor Agreement, the Agreed Security Principles, perfection requirements and any Permitted Liens, grant liens and security interests on an equal and ratable first-ranking basis, over the assets listed below: - the shares of the Issuer and in the case of any Guarantor incorporated or organized in any Security Jurisdiction outside of the United States, any shares or other ownership interests it owns in any other Guarantor and any shares or ownership interests it owns in a wholly owned Material Subsidiary (as defined herein) incorporated in a Security Jurisdiction (as defined herein); and - in the case of each Guarantor incorporated or organized in a state of the United States, all material assets located in the United States but excluding any real property, deposit accounts and any other bank accounts, any intercompany receivables arising directly or indirectly in connection with any cash management, cash pooling, treasury management, tax arrangements or any similar or equivalent arrangements, any ownership interests in a joint venture or other entity that is not a material subsidiary organized or incorporated in Alderney, Australia, Canada, England and Wales, Gibraltar, Ireland, Isle of Man, Malta, the Netherlands or incorporated in any state of the United States and certain other customary excluded property. 5 ----- (together, the “Collateral”). The security interests confirmed or supplemented under the Security Documents in relation to the Collateral in connection with this Offering of the Notes may be junior to the security interests created over the accessory Collateral pursuant to the Security Documents entered into prior to the Issue Date, under which prior security interests have also been granted in favor of, inter alios, the Security Agent for the benefit of the secured parties. The Intercreditor Agreement provides that such junior security interests will be treated as security interests ranking _pari passu with such prior security interests. However, if the Intercreditor Agreement or the relevant provisions thereof were voided or held to be unenforceable for any reason, Holders of the Notes would not benefit from such first-ranking treatment and would be subordinated, with respect to such security interests, to the prior security interests over the same Collateral. See “Description of the Notes—Security—The Collateral.” The Agreed Security Principles under the Credit Agreement require security to be granted over the shares of each of the companies that are obligors or wholly owned material subsidiaries incorporated in a Security Jurisdiction and otherwise require security on an equal and rateable basis with the Credit Facilities. A combination of these Agreed Security Principles will apply to the security granted in favor of the Notes. The security interests in the Collateral may be released under certain circumstances. See “Description of the Notes—Optional Redemption.” Withholding Taxes: ................** All payments in respect of the Notes or the Notes Guarantees will be made without withholding or deduction for any taxes or other governmental charges, except to the extent required by law. If withholding tax is required by law in Ireland, any jurisdiction from or through which payment on the Notes or the Notes Guarantee is made or any other jurisdiction in which the Issuer or the Guarantors are incorporated or organized, resident or engaged in business for tax purposes or has a permanent establishment, in each case, including any political subdivision or taxing authority or agency thereof or therein in (each, a “Relevant Taxing Jurisdiction”), subject to certain exceptions, the Issuer or the relevant Guarantor, as appropriate, will pay additional amounts so that the net amount received will equal the amounts which would have received in the absence of such withholding. See “Description of the Notes— _Withholding Taxes.”_ Tax Redemption: ....................** If certain changes in the law of any Relevant Taxing Jurisdiction become effective that would impose withholding taxes or other deductions on the payments on the Notes or the Notes Guarantees, as applicable, the Issuer may redeem the Notes of any series in whole, but not in part, at any time, at a redemption price of 100% of the principal amount, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding the date of redemption. See “Description of the Notes—Redemption for Taxation Reasons.” Change of Control: ................** Upon the occurrence of certain events constituting a “change of control,” the Issuer is required to offer to repurchase all outstanding Notes at a purchase price in cash equal to 101% of the aggregate principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the date of purchase. If holders of not less than 90% in aggregate principal amount of all of the then outstanding Notes validly tender such Notes in the event of an offer following a change of control, and the Issuer, or any third party making such an offer purchases all of the Notes validly tendered and not validly withdrawn, the Issuer or such third party will have the right to redeem all Notes that remain outstanding following such purchase. See “Description of the Notes—Repurchase at the Option 7 ----- _of Holders—Change of Control.”_ Certain Covenants: ................** The Indenture will, among other things, restrict the ability of the Company, the Issuer and the other restricted subsidiaries of the Company to: - incur or guarantee additional indebtedness and issue certain preferred stock; - create or permit to exist certain liens; - merge or consolidate with other entities; and - impair the security interests for the benefit of the holders of the Notes. Each of these covenants is subject to significant exceptions and qualifications. See “Description of the Notes—Certain Covenants.” Certain of the covenants will be suspended if and for so long as the Notes achieve investment grade ratings. See “Description of the _Notes—Certain_ _Covenants—Suspension_ _of_ _Covenants_ _on Achievement of Investment Grade Status.” There can be no assurance_ that the Notes will ever achieve an investment grade rating or that any such rating will be maintained. Use of Proceeds: .....................** The proceeds of the offering of the Notes sold on the Issue Date will be used (a) to repay borrowings under the Existing Term Loan B Facility, (b) to repay borrowings under the Revolving Credit Facility and (c) to pay certain costs, fees and expenses in connection with the Transactions. See “Use of Proceeds.” Transfer Restrictions: ............** The Notes and the Notes Guarantees have not been, and will not be, registered under the U.S. federal or state or any foreign securities laws and are subject to restrictions on transferability and resale. See “Transfer Restrictions.” The Issuer has not agreed to, or otherwise undertaken to, register the Notes in the United States (including by way of an exchange offer). No Prior Market: ...................** The Notes will be new securities for which there is currently no established trading market. Certain of the Initial Purchasers have advised us that they intend to make a market in the Notes. However, they are not obligated to do so, and the Initial Purchasers may discontinue any market making at any time at their sole discretion and without notice. Accordingly, there can be no assurances as to the development or liquidity of any market for any of the Notes. Listing: ....................................** Application will be made to the Authority for the listing of and permission to deal in the Notes on the Official List of the Exchange.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Economic downturns and political and market conditions beyond our control, including inflation and a reduction in consumer discretionary spending, could adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: Our financial performance is subject to political and economic conditions in the global economy and the jurisdictions in which we operate and their impact on levels of spending by customers, advertisers and business partners. Economic recessions have had, and may continue to have, far reaching adverse consequences across many industries, including the global entertainment, betting and gaming industries, which may adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations. Additionally, inflation has the potential to adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations by increasing our overall cost structure. The recent significant inflationary trends have had an adverse effect on our cost of labor expenditure, as well as other operating expenses. Moreover, our business is particularly sensitive to reductions from time to time in discretionary consumer spending, which is driven by socioeconomic factors beyond our control. Demand for entertainment and leisure activities, including betting and iGaming, can be affected by changes in the economy and consumer tastes, both of which are difficult to predict and beyond our control. Unfavorable changes in general economic conditions, including recessions, economic slowdowns, sustained high levels of unemployment and rising prices or the perception by consumers of weak or weakening economic conditions, may reduce our customers’ disposable income or result in fewer individuals engaging in entertainment and leisure activities, such as betting, iGaming or daily fantasy sports. As a result, we cannot ensure that the demand for our product offerings will remain consistent. Adverse developments affecting economies throughout the world, including a general tightening of credit availability, decreased liquidity in certain financial markets, inflation, increased interest rates, foreign exchange fluctuations, increased energy costs, acts of war or terrorism, cyber-attacks, transportation disruptions, natural disasters, adverse weather conditions, power loss, declining consumer confidence, sustained high levels of unemployment or significant declines in stock markets, as well as pandemics, epidemics, public health emergencies and the spread of contagious diseases, including the ongoing impact of COVID-19, could lead to a further reduction in discretionary spending on entertainment and leisure activities, such as betting and iGaming, any of which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our business is exposed to competitive pressures given the international nature of competition in online betting and iGaming.
Subsubsection Text: If we are unable to compete effectively, we may lose existing customers and we may not be able to attract new customers. The online betting and iGaming market is increasingly competitive. This competition takes place on an international level and operators around the world leverage that scale to attract customers to their websites, with the implication that the barriers to a customer switching between competing operators are low. We may be unable to respond quickly or adequately to changes in the industry brought on by new products and technologies, the availability of products on other technology platforms and marketing channels, and the introduction of new features and functionality or new marketing and promotional efforts by our existing competitors or new competitors and new technology. Such competitors may spend more money and time on developing and testing products and services, undertake more extensive marketing campaigns, adopt more aggressive pricing or promotional policies or otherwise develop more commercially successful products or services than ours, any of which could negatively impact our business, financial condition and results of operations. Our competitors may also develop products, features or services that are similar to ours or that achieve greater market acceptance. 16 ----- In addition, we are also subject to the risk of further consolidation in the betting and gaming industry, which might result in the formation of a very large or successful competitor to whom we might lose market share. Other competitors may have significantly greater financial, technical and other resources than us in certain jurisdictions or markets in which we operate and they may be able to secure greater liquidity than us. A loss of market share could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. Furthermore, betting and gaming faces competition from other entertainment and leisure activities and there can be no assurance that we will be able to increase or maintain our share of customers’ discretionary spending against such other entertainment and leisure activities.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We may fail to retain existing customers for our betting and iGaming offerings or add new customers or customers could decrease their level of engagement with our betting and iGaming offerings in general.
