Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Net loss margin[(1)] ..................................................................................... (9.1)% (3.9)% (10.3)% Adjusted EBITDA[(2)] ................................................................................ 886 1,141 1,679 Adjusted EBITDA Margin[(2)] ................................................................... 10.7% 12.1% 14.2% Further Adjusted EBITDA[(2)] ................................................................... 1,370 1,288 1,875 Further Adjusted EBITDA Margin[(2)] ....................................................... 16.5% 13.6% 15.9% (1) Net loss margin is net loss divided by revenue. (2) Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA Margin, Further Adjusted EBITDA and Further Adjusted EBITDA Margin are non-GAAP financial measures. See “—Supplemental Disclosure of Non-GAAP Measures” for additional information about these measures and reconciliations to the most directly comparable financial measures calculated in accordance with U.S. GAAP. _Year ended December 31, 2023 compared to year ended December 31, 2022_ Our total revenue grew 24.6%, to $11,790 million for the year ended December 31, 2023. The growth was mainly driven by continued expansion of our player base, with AMPs up 20.3% to 12.3 million and AMP growth across all segments. Our U.S. segment was a key driver of this growth, with revenue 40.7% higher year on year despite the impact of adverse sports results. Sports results are calculated as the difference between our expected net revenue margin for the period and our actual net revenue margin, which were particularly pronounced in the quarter ended December 31, 2023 and had an approximately 7.8 percentage point growth impact. Revenue growth outside of the U.S. of 16.4% year on year was partly driven by strong growth in UKI and in our “Consolidate and Invest” markets within International. We also benefited from the full year consolidation of the Sisal business acquired during 2022, which generated $1,218 million of revenue in the year ended December 31, 2023 and added 7.1 percentage points to Group revenue growth. On a pro forma basis, including Sisal as if it were consolidated for the entirely of both 2022 and 2023, Group revenue grew 17.2% compared with the prior year. This was partly offset by a decrease in revenue in our Australia segment, particularly in racing due to a reduced level of player engagement following easing of COVID-19 restrictions. Cost of sales increased by 28.9% to $6,202 million or by 170 basis points as a percentage of revenue to 52.6% for the year ended December 31, 2023. The increase was primarily driven by the annualization of point of consumption tax rate changes in Australia which were increased during the second half of 2022. Technology, research and development expenses increased by 38.6%, to $765 million for the year ended December 31, 2023, primarily driven by the full year consolidation of Sisal and continued investment in product development to enhance the customer proposition of our brands across the Group, and particularly for FanDuel in our U.S. segment. Sales and marketing expenses increased by 25.3% to $3,776 million for the year ended December 31, 2023 primarily due to an impairment loss of $725 million related to PokerStars’ trademark. This reflects the changes we are implementing to optimize the PokerStars business model such as focused investment in our “Consolidate and Invest” markets while reducing sales and marketing expense in our “Optimize and Maintain” markets. The sales and marketing expense increase also included disciplined investment in the continued expansion of our footprint across the U.S. and in our UKI segment to drive market share gains. Sales and marketing expenses as a percentage of revenue of 32.0% increased by 20 basis points compared with the year ended December 31, 2022 as the impact of the impairment loss offset the efficiencies delivered across our business as a 85 ----- result of (i) a greater proportion of our revenue coming from existing states in the U.S. where the proportionate levels of marketing spend are lower, as well as the benefit from the efficiencies of national advertising; (ii) a more personalized approach to spend within UKI; and (iii) more targeted investment in our International segment. General and administrative expenses increased by 36.1% to $1,596 million for the year ended December 31, 2023. The increase was primarily as a result of (i) the continued expansion of our U.S. business; (ii) the full year consolidation of the Sisal business acquired during 2022; and (iii) an increase in corporate overhead due to greater investment in Group resource, technology, and research and development initiatives. The increase also reflects fees associated with the U.S. listing of Flutter shares of $86 million and the Fox Option arbitration proceedings of $30 million. Operating profit declined by $461 million to $549 million, primarily due to the impairment loss of $725 million relating to the PokerStars trademark which more than offset the strong revenue growth across the Group during the year. Other expense increased by $162 million from an income in the year ended December 31, 2022 of $5 million to an expense in the year ended December 31, 2023 of $157 million. This increase was primarily driven by (i) the impact of a fair value loss on the Fox Option Liability in the year ended December 31, 2023 of $165 million, when compared with a gain of $83 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, and (ii) an increase of $145 million related to the fair value gain on derivative instruments to $7 million in the year ended December 31, 2023, from $152 million in the year ended December 31, 2022. The increase in expense was partly offset by a reduction in expense related to the recognition of a foreign exchange gain of $43 million in the year ended December 31, 2023 as compared with a loss of $162 million in the year ended December 31, 2022. Interest expense, net increased by $173 million to $385 million for the year ended December 31, 2023 primarily as a result of an increase in long-term debt associated with the acquisition of Sisal, along with a higher cost of servicing existing debt during the year. Income tax expense increased by $45 million to $120 million for the year ended December 31, 2023. The movement is primarily due to the change in the mix of profits in the jurisdictions in which the Group has a taxable presence as well as the tax effect of acquisition related intangible assets and internal intangible asset transfers. Net loss increased by $841 million to a net loss of $1,211 million for the year ended December 31, 2023 primarily due to the impairment loss of $725 million which more than offset the strong revenue growth across the Group during the year, while net loss margin increased by 640 basis points to 10.3% as a result of the factors above. Adjusted EBITDA increased by 47.2% to $1,679 million and Further Adjusted EBITDA increased by 45.6% to $1,875 million for the year ended December 31, 2023 reflecting the revenue performance and cost trends outlined above. Adjusted EBITDA Margin increased by 210 basis points from 12.1% to 14.2% and Further Adjusted EBITDA Margin increased by 230 basis points from 13.6% to 15.9% primarily due to (i) a reduction in sales and marketing expense as a percentage of revenue of 480 basis points for the Group driven by a greater proportion of our revenue coming from existing states in the U.S. division, where the proportionate levels of marketing spend are lower than in new states; and (ii) economies of scale driven by expansion into new states in the U.S. These were partially offset by the impact of the annualization of point of consumption tax rate increases in Australia which came into effect during the second half of 2022. _Year ended December 31, 2022 compared to year ended December 31, 2021_ Our total revenue grew 13.9% to $9,463 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. The growth was mainly driven by continued expansion of our player base, with AMPs up 25.8% to 10.2 million. Our rapidly scaling U.S. segment was a key driver of this growth, with revenue 66.4% higher year on year. Revenue outside of the U.S. declined 1.8% year on year reflecting (i) the impact of disruption to our International business in Russia and Ukraine due to the ongoing conflict in the region and (ii) decrease in revenue in our Australia segment due to reduced level of player engagement following easing of COVID-19 restrictions and a highly competitive trading environment with new brands entering the market. These were mostly offset by the benefit from our acquisitions of Sisal in the International segment and tombola in the UKI segment during the year ended December 31, 2022. 86 ----- Cost of sales increased by 24.0% to $4,813 million or by 420 basis points as a percentage of revenue to 50.9% for the year ended December 31, 2022. The increase was primarily driven by the launch of our operations in New York State, where gaming taxes are higher, as well as an increase in point of consumption tax rates in Australia during the second half of 2022. Technology, research and development expenses decreased by 12.9% to $552 million primarily driven by the higher share-based payment charge in the year ended December 31, 2021 following a modification of the FanDuel Group Value Creation Plan (“VCP”) in the U.S. division. Sales and marketing expenses increased by 6.9%, to $3,014 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 due to (i) continued expansion of our footprint across the U.S.; (ii) ongoing investment in our “Consolidate _and Invest” markets in International; and (iii) additional amortization in relation to Sisal’s brand and player_ relationships. Sales and marketing expenses as a percentage of revenue decreased to 31.9% for the year ended December 31, 2022 from 33.9% for the year ended December 31, 2021 as a result of (i) a greater proportion of our revenue coming from states where we have an existing presence in the U.S. where the proportionate levels of marketing spend are lower, as well as expansion of our footprint across the U.S. which enabled us to benefit from the efficiencies of national advertising; (ii) the realization of efficiencies in marketing spend within UKI; and (iii) lower level of sales and marketing expenses in Sisal compared with the rest of the Group due to the advertising ban in the Italian market. General and administrative expenses decreased by 17.6%, to $1,172 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. The decrease is primarily as a result of (i) the legal settlement together with associated legal costs amounting $223 million incurred in the year ended December 31, 2021 when Flutter settled the legal dispute with the Commonwealth of Kentucky and (ii) a significant incremental share-based payment charge in 2021 following a modification of the VCP in the U.S. division. This is partially offset by (i) the continued expansion of our footprint across the U.S. and (ii) the acquisition of Sisal. General and administrative expenses as a percentage of revenue decreased to 12.4% for the year ended December 31, 2022 from 17.1% for the year ended December 31, 2021 primarily driven by economies of scale in the U.S. Operating loss decreased by $361 million to a loss of $88 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 from a loss of $449 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 as a result of the factors above. Other income, net decreased by $96 million to $5 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 from $101 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. This was primarily because of a loss on settlement of longterm debt of $65 million in the year ended December 31, 2022 as compared with a gain of $130 million in the year ended December 31, 2021, together with a foreign exchange loss of $162 million in the year ended December 31, 2022 as compared to a loss of $86 million in the year ended December 31, 2021, offset by a fair value gain on the Fox Option of $83 million in the year ended December 31, 2022 as compared to a loss of $71 million in the year ended December 31, 2021, and by a fair value gain on derivative instruments of $152 million in the year ended December 31, 2022 as compared with a gain of $141 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. Interest expense, net decreased by $3 million to $212 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. Income tax expense decreased by $119 million to $75 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 from $194 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. The movement reflected the increase of tax credit of $135 million arising primarily from the tax effect of acquisition-related intangible amortization and the recognition of a deferred tax asset following an internal transfer of intangible assets. This was partly offset by the increase in current tax charge due to increased profit and changes in statutory tax rates in certain jurisdictions. Net loss decreased $387 million to $370 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 from $757 million for the year ended December 31, 2021 as a result of the factors above. Net loss margin decreased from 9.1% to 3.9%, which was primarily due to (i) a greater proportion of our revenue coming from states where we have an existing presence in the U.S. division, where the proportionate levels of marketing spend are lower than in new states; (ii) economies of scale within general and administrative expenses driven by expansion into new states in the United States; (iii) a significant incremental share-based payment charge in 2021 following a modification of the VCP in the U.S. division; (iv) a fair value gain on the Fox Option of $83 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, as compared to a loss of $71 million in the year ended December 31, 2021; and (v) a decrease in income tax charge of $119 million, mainly driven by a tax credit of $135 million arising primarily from the tax effect of acquisition-related intangible amortization and the recognition of a deferred tax asset following an internal transfer of intangible assets. These were partially offset by a loss on settlement of long-term debt of $65 million in the 87 ----- year ended December 31, 2022, as compared with a gain of $130 million in the year ended December 31, 2021, together with an increase in foreign exchange loss of $76 million in the year ended December 31, 2022. Adjusted EBITDA increased by 28.8% to $1,141 million, reflecting the revenue performance and cost trends outlined above. Adjusted EBITDA Margin increased 140 basis points to 12.1%, primarily due to (i) a greater proportion of our revenue coming from states where we have an existing presence in the U.S. division, where the proportionate levels of marketing spend are lower than in new states; (ii) economies of scale within general and administrative expenses driven by expansion into new states in the U.S.; and (iii) a significant incremental share-based payment charge in the year ended December 31, 2021 following a modification of the VCP in the U.S. division offset by the impact of disruption to our International business in Russia and Ukraine due to the ongoing conflict in the region and an increase in point of consumption tax rates in Australia during the second half of 2022. Further Adjusted EBITDA decreased by 6.0% to $1,288 million for 2022 and Further Adjusted EBITDA Margin decreased 290 basis points from 16.5% to 13.6%. This reflects all the items noted above but excludes the impact of the lower share-based payment charge, including a significant incremental sharebased payment charge in 2021 following a modification of the VCP in the U.S. division.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _The following discussion and analysis of our results of operations covers the Group’s last three financial years. You should read the following discussion of our results of operations and financial discussion in conjunction with the consolidated financial statements and related notes, and the information presented in the sections entitled “Selected Historical Financial Information,” appearing elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. This discussion contains forward-looking statements that involve numerous risks and uncertainties, including, but not limited to, those described in the “Risk Factors” section of this Offering Memorandum. Actual results may differ materially from those contained in any forward-looking statements._

The global betting and gaming market, across both land-based and online channels, reached $544.2 billion in gross gaming revenue (“GGR”) in 2023[(1)] and is expected to reach $582.2 billion in 2024 according to data published by H2 Gambling Capital (“H2GC”) in February 2024. The market remained resilient during the global financial crisis (“GFC”), with a growth rate of 2.7% YoY in 2008 and 0.7% YoY in 2009, and a compound annual growth rate (“CAGR”) of 3.6% for the period between 2007 and 2023. While the response to COVID-19 led to the closure of the gaming retail venues and interruption of operations in the global betting and gaming industry in 2020 and 2021, it also accelerated the migration toward online betting and gaming channels from land-based channels. In 2019, the online betting and gaming segment accounted for 15% of the global betting and gaming market in terms of GGR and it is expected to account for 26% in 2024 ($151.9 billion of the total $582.2 billion global betting and gaming market), with significant potential for future growth according to H2GC. The global online betting and gaming market is currently expected to grow at a CAGR of 10.9% between 2024 and 2028, primarily driven by further migration to online channels and the increase in the number of regulated markets across the world. The recent approval of a new regulatory framework for sports betting and iGaming in Brazil in December 2023, and the expected regulation in the next two years of markets such as Canada, as well as additional states in the United States, have the potential to increase the international addressable market.

(1) GGR in 2023 presents provisional results as a combination of actual reported data and estimates depending on the markets and on the product within each market. (2) GGR is defined as gross win by the operators by H2 Gaming Capital, which refers to stakes minus prizes but including bonuses. (3) Land-based refers to GGR from all physical betting and gaming activity processed at licensed premises, including casino, bingo, poker and sports betting. (4) Online refers to GGR from all interactive betting and gaming channels, where the operator has a license or pays tax in the same jurisdiction in which the player is located, including casino, bingo, poker and sports betting. 109 ----- The United States is considered to be the largest growth opportunity, with an estimated total addressable market (“TAM”) in excess of $40 billion by 2030 according to management estimates. Outside of the United States, there is also a long runway for high growth. According to H2GC, the global betting and gaming market ex-US reached $384.3 billion in 2023 and is expected to reach $413.0 billion in 2024 with 30% online penetration. For the period between 2024 and 2028, the market ex-US is expected to grow at a CAGR of 5.0% while the online GGR is projected to grow at a CAGR of 9.2% for the same period. Excluding the UK & Ireland and Australia, the global betting and gaming market ex-US for the rest of world reached $338.6 billion in 2023, of which only $172 billion is in regulated or regulating markets as of today, representing a significant untapped regulated market. The consistent historical growth and strong momentum of the global betting and gaming market have been driven by a number of key factors: - _Channel migration: Prior to COVID-19, the ex-US online betting and gaming market grew at a CAGR of 13.8% from 2007 to 2019 and 2.4% for the land-based betting and gaming during the same period. The global betting and gaming sector was transitioning toward omni-channel platforms from primarily land-based channels historically, driven by the structural shift in consumer preference towards online betting and gaming, as observed in other consumer-facing sectors. The online migration was further accelerated during COVID-19 as retail venues were temporarily closed and consumers substituted online alternatives. - _New regulated and regulating markets:_ There has been significant development towards regulation across key markets, such as Brazil, Canada, as well as the continued opening of new states in the United Stated for betting and gaming since 2018. Notably, on December 29, 2023, a new regulatory framework for sports betting and iGaming in Brazil was approved. Such constructive regulatory developments provide existing betting and gaming operators with access to new markets and customers and the prospect of more sustainable revenue growth once such markets are fully regulated. While regulation creates additional overheads, startup costs and gaming taxes for operators, it makes it more difficult for new market entrants and creates the significant opportunity for the leading existing operators that can utilize their existing market position, scale, and experience to successfully setup operations in new markets. - _New product and technology development: Increasing high-speed internet access and the growth of smart phone usage have spurred demand for more sophisticated and appealing online games. Based on technological advancements, operators continue to invest in the new digital products that offer more engaging and higher-quality gaming experiences for customers. Differentiated product offerings that are intentionally designed for online platforms have become crucial for operators to acquire and retain new customers. - _Increasing recreational customer base:_ The global customer base is becoming more focused on recreational betting and gaming. Betting and gaming have also gained broader recognition as culturally acceptable leisure activities, supported by a broader digital offering, more recreational games and increasingly accessible platforms on mobile phones and the internet. - _Sector consolidation:_ In recent years, gaming operators have actively consolidated their market position through acquisitions, driven in part by the economies of scale and the benefits of diversification. The overlapping cost base from marketing, content development and purchasing, as well as investment in technology, can be effectively reduced, while revenue synergies can be achieved through cross-selling of products across an enlarged customer base. In addition, geographic diversification allows operators to mitigate the exposure to a single regulatory and tax regime, and the diversification across channels allows to cross-sell products across both land-based and online channels.

In the United States, gambling is regulated at both the state and federal levels. In 2018, the U.S. Supreme Court overturned key gambling legislation, the Professional and Amateur Sports Protection Act (“PASPA”), which prohibited the expansion of sports betting nationwide, following an appeal by the state 110 ----- of New Jersey. A number of states have since moved to legalize and regulate gambling at the state level. As of December 31, 2023, 35 states have legalized and regulated retail sports betting, 28 states have legalized and regulated online sports betting and six states have legalized and regulated iGaming. For the twelve months ended November 30, 2023, the states in which the Group was operating generated $15.3 billion in online GGR. According to the Group’s estimates, the TAM for the United States is projected to be over $40 billion by 2030, an expansion to 80% of the population in sportsbook and an expansion to 25% of the population in iGaming. There is also potential for the TAM to exceed these expectations, as existing U.S. states continue to grow beyond 2030 and following the potential legalization of gambling in any additional states.

The United Kingdom is one of largest regulated markets in Europe with a betting and gaming market of $20.4 billion in 2023 based on GGR, according to H2GC. Between the United Kingdom and Ireland, the betting and gaming market reached $22.8 billion in 2023 based on GGR, and since 2022 exceeded 2019 levels with online gaming largely driving the recovery. The market is expected to reach $23.0 billion in 2024, according to H2GC. While more mature and developed than many other European markets, the United Kingdom and Ireland online gaming and betting market has continued to exhibit strong levels of growth, delivering a CAGR of 7.2% between 2016 and 2023 according to H2GC. The majority of this growth has been in the recreational section of the market. Online penetration of the overall market remains elevated as compared to pre-COVID-19 levels, representing approximately 55% in 2023, based on GGR according to H2GC. The migration of customers from offline channels to online channels accelerated during COVID-19 as retail venues were temporarily closed. In the near term, regulatory changes and the introduction of safer gambling initiatives by operators in the United Kingdom and Ireland have led to slightly slower market growth in 2022 and 2023. However, over the medium-term, the recreational customer base is expected to continue to drive further growth in the online gaming and betting market. 111 -----

Separately, while the recent increase in cost of living and inflationary pressures have impacted consumer sentiment in the United Kingdom, the UK betting and gaming market has proven to be resilient, recovering from COVID-19 to above 2019 levels in 2022. The market has benefited from secular tailwinds as increases of online and mobile penetration as well as new product and technology development. As evidenced by the GFC, the betting and gaming market is viewed as resilient through economic downturns. In the United Kingdom, the market grew at a CAGR of 3.1% between 2007 and 2023 and remained stable during the GFC, while GDP contracted by 4.6% in 2009. As referenced above, this time period reflects secular tailwinds with increases of online channelization and mobile penetration.

Subsubsection Title: The UK Gambling Act and UK White Paper Review
Subsubsection Text: In December 2020, the UK government commenced a review of the UK Gambling Act, with the objective of: (i) examining whether changes are needed to the system of gambling regulation in Great Britain to reflect changes to the gambling landscape since 2005 when the UK Gambling Act was introduced, particularly in light of technological advances; (ii) ensuring there is an appropriate balance between consumer freedoms and choice on the one hand, and prevention of harm to vulnerable groups and wider 112 ----- communities on the other; and (iii) ensuring customers are suitably protected during gambling, and that there is an equitable approach to the regulation of the online and the land-based industries. The UK government’s review of the UK Gambling Act is extensive in scope. Key areas under review include: - the effectiveness of the existing online protections in preventing gambling harm and an evidence-based consideration of, for example, imposing greater control on online product design such as stake, speed and prize limits, and the introduction of deposit, loss and spend limits; - the benefits or harms caused by allowing licensed gambling operators to advertise and make promotional offers and the positive or negative impact of gambling sponsorship arrangements across sports, e-sports and other areas; - the effectiveness of the regulatory system currently in place, including consideration of whether the UKGC has sufficient investigative, enforcement and sanctioning powers both to regulate the licensed market and address the unlicensed market; - the availability and suitability of redress arrangements in place for an individual consumer who considers it may have been treated unfairly by a gambling operator, including consideration of the introduction of other routes for consumer redress, such as a gambling ombudsman; and - the effectiveness of current measures to prevent illegal underage gambling and consideration of what extra protections may be needed for young adults in the 18−25 age bracket. The call for evidence in connection with the review concluded in March 2021. On April 27, 2023, the UK government issued a white paper, which included proposals to: - hold a consultation to determine the maximum staking limit for online slot gaming products of between £2 and £15 per spin, with options of a £2 limit per stake, £4 limit per stake or an approach based on individual risk for 18-24 year-old players; - hold a consultation to determine whether to make player-set deposit limits mandatory or opt-out rather than opt-in; - introduce a statutory levy (as a percentage of revenue) requiring all licensed operators to make contributions to help fund research, education and treatment of gambling harms.; and - hold a consultation on imposing new obligations on licensed operators to conduct: - enhanced spending checks if a player loses £1,000 within one day or £2,000 within 90 days, with such thresholds halved for 18-24 year-old players; and - financial vulnerability checks if a player loses more than £125 within one month or £500 within one year. In line with its strategy to take a leadership role in responsible betting and gaming, Flutter has implemented a broad range of player protections over the last three years during the pendency of the UK government’s review of the UK Gambling Act. We estimate that these changes have resulted in a loss of £150 million in annual revenue from our UKI business and that the incremental revenue impact from the proposed measures announced in the white paper could be between £50 million and £100 million, resulting in a total cumulative revenue impact of between £200 million and £250 million of annual UKI revenue. For additional information on the UK Gambling Act and UK White Paper Review, see “Risk _Factors—_ _Risks Relating to Regulation, Licensing, Litigation and Taxation —The UK government’s ongoing review of the UK Gambling Act may result in more onerous regulation of the betting and gaming industry in the United Kingdom, our second-largest market, which could have a material adverse effect on_ 113 ----- _our business, financial condition and results of operations.” See also “Business—Regulation—UK and Ireland—United Kingdom.”_

Subsubsection Text: The Australian betting and gaming market is regulated at the federal and state levels. According to H2GC, the market generated GGR of US$19.1 billion in 2019 and reached GGR of US$22.9 billion in 2023, above pre-COVID-19 levels, with online betting and gaming accounting for 26% of the market in 2023. Between 2016 and 2023, the Australian online betting and gambling market grew at a CAGR of 10.5% based on GGR according to H2GC, with future growth rates expected to be dependent on: (i) the rate of retention of customers who have migrated to online betting and gaming channels from land-based betting and gaming channels and (ii) increase in new recreational customers that are avid sports fans who do not currently bet a bookmaker and who opt instead to place their sports bets online. In the recent years, the Australian market has benefitted from customer migration to online channels, accelerated by COVID-19 related restrictions in retail channels in 2020 and 2021, and the market also benefited from changes to consumer entertainment spend, as consumers substituted online alternatives for travel and leisure spend. In 2022, the market experienced some reversions of these trends with 4% of the online market returning to the retail channel, and consumers’ entertainment and travel options restored. Post-COVID-19 softening of consumer demand has also affected the racing market in particular, given it was a disproportionate beneficiary of COVID-19 tailwinds. While the softer racing market is expected to continue in the near term, the sports segment of the market has shown continued growth.

(2) GGR in 2023 presents provisional results as a combination of actual reported data and estimates depending on the markets and on the product within each market. The regulatory environment in Australia has evolved significantly in recent years, especially after the introduction of point of consumption tax in 2019. Queensland made two changes to point of consumption tax, effective from December 1, 2022, including increasing the rate from 15% of gross revenue to 20% and including into scope the taxing of Freebet stakes. New South Wales increased the point of consumption tax rate from 10% to 15%, effective from July 1, 2022. Effective from July 1, 2023, the Australian Capital Territory raised the point of consumption tax rate from 20% to 25%. And finally, Victoria announced an increase in the point of consumption tax rate from 10% to 15%, effective from July 1, 2024. The higher tax environment underlines the importance of scale in the Australian market and favours large operators, as increasing regulatory and tax hurdles can drive out smaller operators and support market share expansion for scale operators. Despite regulatory changes in the recent history, the Australian gaming and betting market showed resilience, having grown at a CAGR of 3.7% between 2007 and 2023. During the GFC, while the real GDP 114 ----- 60.0 40.0 20.0 0.0 growth slowed to 1.9% in 2009, the gaming market grew by 5.2% year-on-year before contracting by 0.3% in 2010 and expanding again by 5.4% and 6.0% in 2011 and 2012, respectively.

Italy is the largest regulated gambling market in the European Union with $22.2 billion GGR in 2019. The market had remained stable in recent years prior to COVID-19, which saw land-based retail outlets close during 2020 and 2021. The market began recovering as COVID-19 related restrictions eased in 2021 and has exceeded its pre-pandemic levels in 2022 and 2023 with $22.9 billion and $23.9 billion GGR according to H2GC. The market is projected to reach $25.6 billion GGR in 2024 and the online penetration is expected to stand at 22% based on GGR in 2024 compared with 55% in the United Kingdom and Ireland, which represents an opportunity for Italian online betting and gaming to further grow given the under-penetration in this market. 115 -----
Our international division operates in over 100 different countries in both regulated and unregulated markets with select markets discussed below.

Subsection Title: Italy Betting and Gaming Market GGR (in $billion)

Subsubsection Text: Among international markets in which we operate, Turkey, India, Georgia, and Spain are our four largest markets after Italy. These markets represent either (a) markets in which the Group is consolidating its number 1 positions to drive profitable growth, such as Spain and Georgia, or (b) markets in which the Group is investing to achieve leadership positions given the high growth potential in those markets such as in India and Turkey. According to H2GC, the betting and gaming market reached $2.2 billion GGR in Turkey, $8.7 billion in India, $1.2 billion in Georgia and $12.6 billion in Spain in 2023 and is expected to reach $2.7 billion GGR in Turkey, $10.0 billion in India, $1.3 billion in Georgia and $13.1 billion in Spain in 2024, resulting in total GGR of $27.1 billion for these four markets in 2024. For the period between 2016 and 2023, the market grew at a CAGR of 27.2%, 22.9% and 21.5% in Turkey, India, and Georgia, respectively, driven by the fast-growing online channel. While the market grew at a CAGR of 2.5% in Spain for the same period, the online segment grew at a CAGR of 10.9%. 116 -----

5.7 1.6 2.0 2.2 2.5 **17.8** 4.6 5.2 **14.7** 4.7 3.2 20.3 19.8 19.4 19.7 18.3 18.7 19.8 11.5 13.1 (1) 2016 2017 2018 2019 2020 2021 2022 2023P 2024E Land-based Online % Online penetration rate _Source: H2 Gambling Capital, February 2024._ (1) GGR in 2023 presents provisional results as a combination of actual reported data and estimates depending on the markets and on the product within each market. The Italian gambling market has historically seen significant progress in the liberalization of its regulatory framework, starting with the legalization of betting in 2007. In the past decade, the industry has further benefited from retail network modernization, new product and technology rollouts, an increase in the average pay-out, as well as stricter controls on illegal gambling operations and more emphasis on safe gambling. In recent years, the regulatory framework in Italy has tightened with an online advertising ban issued in 2019 as well as an increase in tax on gross win for sports betting and gaming. An additional tax on sports betting was introduced in 2020 by the Italian government that will be levied until the end of 2022 as part of COVID-19 recovery plans. In January 2024, the Italian government approved the terms of the Reorganisation Decree which will undertake the first regulatory evaluation of the Italian gambling market since its authorization in 2011. The Reorganisation Decree’s primary objectives are enhanced player protection, combating illegal gambling and increased tax revenue through a new licensing framework. However, compared to small operators, large omni-channel operators are less impacted by the recent regulatory changes due to less reliance on online advertising and the advantage of scale. In addition, the online gaming operators with retail outlets are particularly well positioned in Italy to benefit from the migration of customers to the market’s online channel as a significant proportion of deposits and withdrawals for online betting and gaming are conducted via retail networks in Italy and the ability to engage customers across both channels provides a distinct advantage.

(3) Converted to USD from GEL at 0.3718 GEL/USD exchange rate, which represents the spot exchange rate as of 31 December 2023. (4) Converted to USD from EUR at 1.1039 EUR/USD exchange rate, which represents the spot exchange rate as of 31 December 2023. 117 -----

Flutter is the world’s leading online sports betting and iGaming operator with 12.3 million Average Monthly Players (“AMPs”) and $11.8 billion of revenue globally for the year ended December 31, 2023. Our Group consists of a diverse portfolio of leading recreational brands and products with a broad global reach and expansive market share, with more than 76.0% of our revenue for the year ended December 31, 2023 generated within geographies in which we occupy a number-one position. Across key regulated markets, we hold multiple top-three positions, including number one in the United States for the year ended December 31, 2023, the UK and Ireland for the year ended December 31, 2023 and Australia for the year ended December 31, 2023. Our 23,053 employees across 23 countries operate some of the world’s most innovative, diverse and distinctive online gaming and sports betting brands such as FanDuel, Sky Betting & Gaming, Sportsbet, PokerStars, Paddy Power, Sisal, tombola, MaxBet, Betfair, TVG, Junglee Games and Adjarabet. Flutter has been operating since 1988 and is headquartered in Dublin, Ireland. We operate a divisional management and operating structure across our geographic markets. Each division has a talented and empowered management team, which is responsible for maintaining the momentum and growth in our respective geographic markets. Our divisions are: (i) the United States (“U.S.”), (ii) the UK and Ireland (“UKI”), (iii) Australia and (iv) International. In our UKI division, we hold the leading market position in online gaming and sports betting by net gaming revenue, in the year ended December 31, 2023, and our brands include some of the most popular online gaming and sports betting brands, such as Sky Betting & Gaming, Paddy Power (in which we have both an online and retail offering, including 576 retail shops), Betfair and tombola. In our Australia division, our Sportsbet brand is the market leader in online sports betting, representing an estimated 45% of the online market share in Australia based on gross gaming revenue from online betting and gaming for the year ended December 31, 2023. Our U.S. division includes FanDuel, which is the online sportsbook market leader for the year ended December 31, 2023, currently available in 22 U.S. states, and our iGaming offering, available in five U.S. states. We expect our presence in the United States to increase as additional states legalize online gambling. Our International division operates in over 100 countries and includes the global brands of PokerStars and Betfair, as well as local brands such as Adjarabet and Junglee Games. For the years ended December 31, 2023, 90.1% of our revenue was generated from our online businesses. As of March 26, 2024, our online operations are complemented by our 1,165 retail shops in Armenia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Georgia, Italy, Ireland, Montenegro, North Macedonia, Serbia, the United Kingdom and the United States. Our iGaming products are provided across our online business in many, but not all, jurisdictions in which we offer our sports services.

Subsubsection Title: We are well positioned to capitalize on growth in the global online betting and gaming market, which has a significant runway for future growth, with the United States providing the most exciting opportunity today
Subsubsection Text: The global online betting and gaming market has significant potential for future growth, with more U.S. states expected to regulate online betting and gaming in the coming years. The United States is our most significant market opportunity. FanDuel has continued to see positive legislative momentum, resulting in its online sportsbook being available in 20 U.S. states (Vermont and North Carolina were added in the fiscal quarter ended March 31, 2024) and iGaming being available in five U.S. states as of the last twelve months ended November 30, 2023, representing 45.0% of the U.S. population and 11.5% of the U.S. population, respectively. We expect the total addressable market (“TAM”) for the United States to be greater than $40 billion by 2030 as a result of (i) the maturation of states with existing sports betting and gaming and (ii) the expansion of legalized sports betting and gaming to cover approximately 80% and 25% of the U.S. population, respectively. Our U.S. division saw its market share reach 37%, including an online sportsbook market share based on gross gaming revenue from online sportsbook of 43.2% for the three months ended December 31, 2023, or 53.4% based on net gaming revenue (based on data received from reporting states only). This 118 ----- leading market position was driven by efficient customer acquisition and retention, high-quality products and effective execution of our strategies, and it has enabled us to fully capitalize on our significant opportunity in the United States, as evidenced by our delivery of a positive US Adjusted EBITDA ($65 million) as well as positive US Further Adjusted EBITDA ($167 million) for the year ended December 31, 2023. Outside of the United States, we estimate that the total betting and gaming market was worth $384 billion in 2023, with 30% of this market occurring online. We also estimate that, of the $339 billion TAM outside of the United States, the United Kingdom, Ireland and Australia, $172 billion occurred in regulating or regulated markets, representing a significant opportunity for further growth internationally. We believe our scale and market leading positions in our online betting and gaming markets will enable us to (i) proactively prepare for new market openings and capture and consolidate market share, (ii) continue to benefit from the shift from in person to online betting and gaming and (iii) operate a resilient business model which we believe has allowed us to continue growing through regulatory changes.

Subsubsection Title: We are a global leader and scale operator in online gaming and sports betting with a diversified portfolio of leading brands
Subsubsection Text: We are a leading global online gaming and sports betting operator with 12.3 million AMPs and $11.8 billion of revenue globally, which is 2.5x the revenue of our next largest peer, for the year ended December 31, 2023. We believe our scale provides us with a key advantage over competitors and has contributed to leading positions in our key markets. We held a leading 37% market share (including an online sportsbook market share of 43.2% and an iGaming market share of 25.7%) in the United States for the three months ended December 31, 2023, while our U.S. division revenue grew 40.7% between December 31, 2022 and December 31, 2023. Our leading UKI division had an online market share of 30% (including a sportsbook market share of 41% and an iGaming market share of 23%), based on net gaming revenue from online sportsbook and gaming, for the year ended December 31, 2023. In Australia, Sportsbet enjoyed a leading position, holding an estimated online market share of 45% based on gross gaming revenue from online sports betting and gaming in the year ended December 31, 2023. Throughout our International division, our brands held a range of top-three positions across various geographic markets for the year ended December 31, 2023. Our leading brands, which are among the most recognizable in their markets, include: FanDuel, Sky Betting & Gaming, Sportsbet, PokerStars, Paddy Power, Sisal, tombola, MaxBet, Betfair, TVG, Junglee Games and Adjarabet. The acquisition of Sisal in August 2022 has further improved our broad and geographically diverse offering, increasing our exposure in Italy, which is Europe’s largest regulated gaming market. Additionally, the acquisition of MaxBet in January 2024 added a local hero brand to our portfolio in Serbia, a fast growing regulated market. We believe the diversified nature of our brand portfolio, product mix and geographic footprint has historically delivered a resilient business model and positions us well to capitalize on future growth opportunities.

Subsubsection Title: Access to global sector expertise, including an experienced management team focused on delivering our refreshed, a compelling three pillar strategy, and proprietary technology platforms and capabilities drive distinct competitive advantages
Subsubsection Text: Our brands have access to the operating scale of a leader across product, technology, people and capital. We believe that the availability of this company-wide expertise, as and when our brands need it, provides us with a distinctive set of advantages. We devote substantial resources to delivering the best products to our customers. We devote significant capital expenditures in developing and maintaining our proprietary technology as well as to the employment of approximately 7,000 technologists, including approximately 3,200 software engineers, around the Group to which our brands have access. The benefits of our multi-decade investment are available to all our brands, ensuring we are driving market trends and strengthening our compelling customer proposition across the Group, while delivering the benefits of our global scale across each of our local brands. We believe that the market-leading pricing and risk management capabilities underpinning our sportsbook product innovations for each of our sportsbook businesses showcase the benefits of our 119 ----- investment in technology. For example, we first launched the “Same Game Multi” product in Australia and subsequently launched it in other markets around the globe, including as “Same Game Parlay” in the United States. We believe that our investment in technology underlies our competitive advantage in gaming as well. Our four in-house studios provide access to proprietary gaming content which is delivered across the Group to our gaming brands. We have also successfully utilized innovation in our UKI business to drive player engagement, including daily prize mechanics such as Sky Betting & Gaming’s “Prize Machine” and Paddy Power’s “Wonder Wheel.” These innovations have helped to drive gaming momentum, and we have deployed these successes in our other businesses as well, as demonstrated by the launch of the PokerStars “Spin of the Day” mechanic in 2022 and FanDuel’s Reward Machine in 2023. We share access to people and talent across our Group, ensuring our businesses utilize the sector expertise we have built over decades across our diverse portfolio of brands and products. We are led by an experienced, entrepreneurial management team committed to realizing our Group strategy. Our management team is highly qualified and has a track record of navigating regulatory changes while continuing to grow our business. Our management team has demonstrated success with integrating mergers and acquisitions into the existing Group and in realizing synergies created by these acquisitions. The numerous significant mergers and acquisitions that our management team has led us through in our recent history include the acquisitions of Sisal, tombola, MaxBet, Adjarabet and Junglee.

Subsubsection Title: We have a track record of setting and delivering the right strategic priorities
Subsubsection Text: We believe that we have identified the right strategic priorities through our Group strategy and that continued progress on our strategy will continue to deliver sustainable revenue growth along with scale and leadership benefits which will improve profitability and cash flow generation. For example, by setting a clearly defined strategy for success in the United States and effectively executing that strategy, we have developed a profitable business model with revenue generated by existing players funding the cost of player acquisitions and operating expenses, leading to a US Adjusted EBITDA of $65 million and US Further Adjusted EBITDA of $167 million for the year ended December 31, 2023. The Group outside of the U.S. division experienced revenue, Adjusted EBITDA and Further Adjusted EBITDA growth. Revenue outside the United States grew 16%, Group Ex-US Adjusted EBITDA grew 8.5% and Group Ex-US Further Adjusted EBITDA grew 10% year over year between December 31, 2022 and 2023, driven by the acquisition of Sisal, strong AMP growth, enhanced product and generosity initiatives. This was partly offset by lower Adjusted EBITDA and Further Adjusted EBITDA in Australia due to COVID-19 spend reversion, a softer racing market in Australia, and the annualized impact of increased point of consumption tax rate in 2022. Adjusted EBITDA and Further Adjusted EBITDA growth over the same period was also driven by the “Consolidate and Invest” markets within our International division where we aim to build and maintain our leadership positions (including Italy, Spain, Georgia, Armenia, Brazil, India, and Turkey), where revenue grew 14% and Sisal online revenue grew 20% on a pro forma basis to include the Sisal acquisition as if Sisal had been acquired as of January 1, 2022. Group ExUS Adjusted EBITDA Margin and Group Ex-US Further Adjusted EBITDA Margin decreased by 1.7 and 1.4 percentage points, respectively, year over year between December 31, 2022 and 2023, primarily driven by the Australian trends noted above. We also believe that our financial profile showcases a commitment to a disciplined financial policy that is supported by a cash-generative model that we believe to be highly attractive. For the year ended December 31, 2023, we generated $937 million net cash provided by operating activities (2022: $1,163 million) and $938 million of Adjusted Free Cash Flow, 1.6 times our Adjusted Free Cash Flow generated in the year ended December 31, 2022 as a result of strong EBITDA growth, positive working capital movements and, low capital intensity. Our U.S. business generated positive Adjusted EBITDA and Further Adjusted EBITDA in the year ended December 31, 2023, and we believe the ongoing deleveraging impact of the growing U.S. business positions us well to achieve our medium-term leverage goals.

Subsubsection Title: We are focused on driving sustainable long-term success
Subsubsection Text: In February 2022, we launched our “Positive Impact Plan.” Using our global scale combined with local focus, this new Group-wide sustainability strategy builds on the progress we have already made across 120 ----- our three key focus areas – our customers, our colleagues and our communities – and also includes our efforts to reduce our environmental footprint. Devised and driven by our employees, our Positive Impact Plan creates a consistent global approach that aligns with our corporate strategy and gives our diverse portfolio of brands better access to the insights, skills and capabilities of the wider Group in order to develop and deliver local initiatives that create maximum impact. The plan focuses on three key areas of sustainability for the future, with clear long-term goals to: - Help customers Play Well: our goal is to increase the proportion of our online customers that use at least one of our safer gambling tools. As of December 31, 2023, 44.9% of our active online customers were already utilizing our safer gambling tools, increasing from 40.8% as of December 31, 2022. - Empower colleagues to Work Better: Our goal is for our teams to be representative of the places in which we live and work, through a comprehensive diversity and inclusion strategy. As of December 31, 2023, 35.7% of leadership roles at Flutter were held by women. - Work with communities to **Do More: our goal is to improve the lives of millions of people through various community support initiatives by using the power of sport and play, the skills of our colleagues and the reach of our brands. While we are actively focused on our three key focus areas, we also recognize the important role we play as a large, multi-national operator to be an industry leader in promoting environmental responsibility. In support of our commitment to reducing our environmental footprint, our Positive Impact Plan also sets environmental goals that include following our roadmap to achieving our net zero ambitions via science-based carbon targets, developing and implementing a global e-waste policy across our divisions and suppliers in the near term and aiming to move all of our energy tariffs, where possible, to renewable energy tariffs over the medium term. We also proactively embrace regulation of our sector, as we recognize such regulation underpins sustainable revenue growth.
We believe that we benefit from the following key strengths that differentiate us from our competitors.

Subsubsection Title: Invest to win in the United States
Subsubsection Text: By building on our sustainable competitive advantages to extend our leadership position in new states and states where we have an existing presence, we believe we are well positioned to act quickly and bolster our leadership in this important market. The first part of our U.S. strategy is to extend our number one position in online sportsbook. Since the repeal of the Professional and Amateur Sports Protection Act (“PASPA”) and the associated start of gambling market liberalization in the United States in 2018, FanDuel has generally been the number one brand in the U.S. market. FanDuel finished the year ended December 31, 2023 with a 43% online sports betting market share, while generating $4.4 billion in revenue for the year ended December 31, 2023. We believe that we will be able to continue to deliver leadership in the U.S. market through the _FanDuel Advantage where we believe that FanDuel is (i) able to acquire players efficiently, (ii) retain players for longer and (iii) earn higher average revenue per player. The second component of our U.S. investment strategy is to utilize our portfolio of assets and our expertise to grow our gaming proposition. We intend to do this by increasing our focus on gaming direct customers, improving the breadth of our product offering in our FanDuel Casino brand and developing engaging promotional tools. 121 -----

Subsubsection Title: Grow our leading market positions in core markets
Subsubsection Text: Our core markets remain a crucial pillar of our strategy. By retaining our challenger mindset and continuing to invest in our brand and product propositions, we intend to extend our leadership position and grow our recreational customer base efficiently, leveraging local scale to unlock benefits across these markets. Our Australia and UKI divisions experienced strong recreational customer growth in the year ended December 31, 2023, with AMPs having increased a combined 9% between the two divisions compared to the year ended December 31, 2022. We believe our scale will position us well to invest in our brand and product leadership to continue to deliver best-in-class experiences to our customers. To build upon the momentum we generated from previous market leading product innovations, such as our Sportsbet “Same Game Multi” and daily prize mechanics, such as the Sky Vegas “Prize Machine,” we intend to continue to invest in our products in order to deliver the next generation of product advantages. In the year ended December 31, 2023, our scale and product leadership enabled us to maintain our gold medal positions in our core markets, including a 2 percentage point increase in our UKI market share. For example, our UKI division launched “Live Casino” products and Sky Bet’s “AccaFreeze” during the year ended December 31, 2023. In addition, the acquisition of Sisal in August 2022 has provided us with another gold medal position in Italy, one of the world’s largest regulated markets. As we further integrate our brands in the UK and Ireland, we intend to utilize our local and global scale to continue delivering growth through regulatory changes and realize further cost efficiencies based on the sharing of our global resources and capabilities.

Subsubsection Title: Build on our network and invest for leadership positions across international markets
Subsubsection Text: As a global operator, we understand that our strength lies in combining our global scale with local knowledge. By utilizing these leadership advantages, we intend to extend our leadership positions internationally through building and buying businesses that occupy top-three market positions in regulated markets to maximize the network benefits of our products. We have identified four key areas to bolster our framework for future growth: - By deploying our resources and capital, we intend to consolidate our number-one positions in our largest markets, such as in Italy following our acquisition of Sisal, thereby driving profitable growth. - We intend to invest for leadership in fast-growing markets, such as India, Brazil, and Turkey, where we have been generating strong returns on incremental product and marketing investments. - We intend to optimize our returns from other regulated markets, mainly across Europe, based on our current market position or market growth outlook. - Maintain our presence in other regulated and regulating markets which are generating positive contribution and/or provide future growth optionality. - We also intend replicate the success we achieved with the acquisitions of Adjarabet and Junglee Games by identifying acquisition targets that are a strategic fit for us, establishing additional leadership positions among the top-three operators in attractive, fast-growing markets where organic growth is slower or more challenging to achieve. The acquisition of MaxBet, which holds a podium position in the attractive Serbian market, in January 2024, is the most recent example of this strategy in action. In the year ended December 31, 2023, we continued to improve our revenue mix across both products and geographies. For the year ended December 31, 2023, the International division contributed 23.9% of our revenue (December 31, 2022: 22%).

Our scale and geographic footprint have been transformed since we set our initial pillared strategy in 2018. With successful progression and delivery against these goals, we refreshed our strategic priorities in 2022 to ensure they reflect our evolving approach. We believe the newly refreshed strategy will deliver and defend leading market positions for our existing businesses as well as ensure the continued cultivation of an innovative mindset that will allow us to capitalize on future opportunities. These new priorities also recognize the role we play as a responsible global leader in our industry by placing sustainability at the heart of everything we do. Our commitment to sustainability is demonstrated by our Positive Impact Plan, discussed above.

The Group is the world’s largest online sports betting and iGaming operator based on revenue. Our ambition is to change our industry for the better and deliver long-term growth, while also achieving a positive, sustainable future for all our stakeholders. We are well-placed to do so through the global 122 ----- competitive advantages of the Flutter Edge, which provides our brands with access to group-wide benefits to stay ahead of the competition while maintaining a clear vision for sustainability through our Positive _Impact Plan._ The Group consists of a diverse portfolio of leading recreational brands and products with a broad international reach. We operate some of the world’s most distinctive online sports betting and iGaming brands which offer our principal product categories of sportsbook, iGaming and other products (exchange betting, pari-mutuel wagering and DFS). These products are offered by FanDuel (sportsbook, iGaming and other products in our U.S. division), Sky Betting & Gaming (sportsbook and iGaming products in our UKI division), Sportsbet (sportsbook products in our Australia division), PokerStars (iGaming products in our International and U.S. divisions), Paddy Power (sportsbook and iGaming products in our UKI division), Sisal (sportsbook and iGaming products, which also includes lottery products, in our International division), tombola (iGaming products in our UKI division), Betfair (sportsbook, iGaming and other products in our UKI and International divisions), TVG (other products in our U.S. division), Junglee Games (iGaming and other products in our International division) and Adjarabet (iGaming products in our International division). In January 2024, we acquired a 51% controlling stake in MaxBet, a leading omni-channel sports betting and gaming operator in Serbia, which offers sportsbook and iGaming products and will be included in our International division from that date. We are the industry leader by size with 12.3 million Average Monthly Players (“AMPs”) and $11,790 million of revenue globally for the year ended December 31, 2023. AMPs refers to the average over the applicable reporting period of the total number of players who have placed and/or wagered a stake and/or contributed to rake (i.e., the commission we take for operating or hosting a game) or tournament fees during the month. This measure does not include individuals who have only used new player or player retention incentives, and this measure is for online players only and excludes retail player activity. See “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Key _Operational Metrics” for additional information regarding how we calculate AMPs data, including a_ discussion regarding duplication of players that exists in such data. We operate a divisional management and operating structure across our geographic markets. Each division has an empowered management team responsible for maintaining the momentum and growth in its respective geographic markets. Our divisions are: (i) the United States (the “U.S.”), (ii) the United Kingdom and Ireland (“UKI”), (iii) Australia and (iv) International, which align with our four reportable segments. We believe that the Group is well positioned to drive future growth due to the following: - **Access to significant** **market opportunity: The U.S. market is expected to continue to experience significant growth as additional U.S. states are expected to legalize sports betting and iGaming, while outside of the U.S., the market is already worth $384 billion and also continues to grow. With just 30% of this combined market opportunity currently taking place online and $172 billion in regulated or regulating markets (excludes countries which, based on Flutter’s judgement, are not addressable by Flutter due to the regulatory regime and/or licensing structure in place), we believe that there is a long runway for future growth. - **Diversified product and geographic portfolio at scale:** We operate in a wide range of markets and offer a broad range of products. This level of diversification gives us exposure to fast-growing markets, and we also believe that it mitigates the impact on the overall Group of regulatory or other changes in individual markets. As a scale operator, we benefit from the “flywheel effect” where higher revenue growth enables greater operating leverage. This in turn enables us to invest more in our products and player proposition. - **The** **_Flutter Edge: We refer to our Group’s global competitive advantage across product, technology, people and capital provided by our scale and experience of operating online sports and betting businesses globally for over 20 years as the “Flutter Edge.” It represents the symbiotic relationship between our teams and divisions, with all contributing to and benefitting from the Flutter Edge. 123 ----- - **Optimal strategy to deliver success: We have a clearly defined Group strategy to enable us to deliver on our strategic priorities: - **Invest to win in the United States by building on our sustainable competitive advantages to extend our leadership position in new states and states where we have an existing presence. We believe that we will be able to continue to deliver leadership in the U.S. market through the FanDuel Advantage where we believe that FanDuel is (i) able to acquire players efficiently, (ii) retain players for longer and (iii) earn higher average revenue per player. - **Grow our gold medal (i.e. market-leading) positions in our other core

Subsection Title: markets of UKI, Australia and Italy by focusing on expanding our player base,
Subsubsection Text: using local scale to unlock benefits across these markets. - **Build on our network and invest for leadership positions across

Subsection Title: international markets by combining global scale with local presence to deliver
Subsubsection Text: sustainable growth. This is underpinned by our sustainability strategy, our Positive Impact Plan, as striving to take care of our players, our colleagues, our communities and our planet is a goal we take very seriously. We view our size and global presence as providing a platform to make a positive, lasting impact on our industry, and we aspire to leverage our local knowledge and agility to do so in a meaningful way. The plan has four elements: - **Customers: Seeking to help customers to “Play Well” through products, tools, technology and dedicated teams designed to support positive play and tailored to local markets. Our Play Well strategy was launched in March 2021 and seeks to empower each division to have ownership over their safer gambling strategy to align with their regulatory obligations and our Play Well principles, while working groups across divisions meet regularly to share best practices and align on key topics. In addition, annual bonuses for our executive directors are determined in part by reference to achievement of certain safer gambling measures. As of December 31, 2023, 44.9% of our active online customers were using at least one Play Well tool, compared to 40.8% as of December 31, 2022. - **Colleagues: Striving to empower colleagues to “Work Better” by building teams that are representative of where we live and work. For example, we have begun taking steps in the area of diversity, equity and inclusion to increase female representation in leadership. As of December 31, 2023, 35.7% of top leadership roles below the Board level were held by women. In addition, we have begun to measure and report on pay performance, progression and retention across different employee demographics and measure employee sentiment across different employee demographics. - **Communities: Seeking to “Do More” to improve the lives of the people in our communities through our corporate social responsibility initiatives and the collective energy of our colleagues and scale of our business, including supporting charitable initiatives through company donations and colleague giving. - **Environment: As the biggest player in our sector, we believe that we have a responsibility to not only reduce our own impact but also lead on climate action, and we seek to reduce our environmental impact through our carbon reduction strategies and transition plans. Although our carbon reduction strategies and transition plans are long-term goals, we have already undertaken certain concrete steps, including establishing an internal environmental working group, enhancing our carbon accounting and assurance procedures, and developing a climate risk framework at the Group level. In addition, we have set a goal to reach net zero carbon emissions by 2035 and continue to take actions as we strive toward that goal, including by assessing and transitioning our real estate 124 ----- footprint, monitoring our emissions and voluntarily submitting our net zero target to the Science Based Target Initiative for their review. While we have adopted various policies and procedures to facilitate the achievement of the goals and targets we have set pursuant to our Positive Impact Plan, they are not ultimately required to be implemented by management and there is no guarantee we will achieve them. As part of our preparation for future reporting obligations, including limited assurance of metrics, as required under the CSRD, we plan to evolve our reporting framework to enhance the overall reporting of our Positive Impact Plan metrics. - **Opportunity for long-term growth through our financial growth engine: We believe that the combination of these factors positions the Group well to capitalize on the future long-term growth of the markets we operate in, through our financial growth engine. This is built on: - **Sustainable revenue growth: We seek to expand the Group’s player base and grow player value through product innovation and efficient generosity spend. We believe that there are significant revenue growth opportunities for both our U.S. and ex-U.S. businesses. As more U.S. states have legalized sports betting and iGaming, our U.S. business has grown revenue by 134.2%, from $1,915 million in the year ended December 31, 2021 to $4,484 million in the year ended December 31, 2023. Excluding the U.S. business, we have grown revenue by 14.3%, from $6,393 million in the year ended December 31, 2021 to $7,306 million in the year ended December 31, 2023, including the benefit of acquisitions during that period, and we believe that our International “Consolidate and Invest” markets, which include Italy, Spain, Georgia, Armenia, Brazil, India and Turkey, provide the platform for continued high levels of future growth. - **Margin benefits: We seek to increase the efficiency of our marketing investment and operating leverage to deliver high net income margins and Adjusted EBITDA Margins. The Group’s net income (loss) margins and Adjusted EBITDA Margins have been negatively impacted in recent years by significant investments in marketing and customer acquisition in the U.S. division. As we deliver against our U.S. strategy, the net income (loss) margin and Adjusted EBITDA Margin of the U.S. division have improved and we expect this trajectory to continue and drive further improvement in our consolidated net income (loss) margin and Adjusted EBITDA Margin over time. - **Significant cashflow generation: Although recent acquisitions have resulted in increased long-term debt, we believe that the low levels of capital intensity due to the scalable nature of our technology platforms, and positive working capital from our expanding business, will permit us to reduce our leverage ratio over time. As of the end of the year ended December 31, 2023 and 2022, we had total long-term debt of $7,056 million and $6,750 million, respectively. - **Disciplined capital allocation: We expect to drive long-term earnings per share growth and long-term value creation through disciplined capital allocation: - **Disciplined organic investment: We believe that our player acquisition cost, lifetime value and player relationship management models and algorithms provide a disciplined evaluation framework enabling high returns from our investment in player growth and retention. - **Value creative M&A:** We have clear criteria for acquiring bolt-on, “local-hero” brands, with podium (i.e. top-three) positions in highgrowth markets. These local heroes are then complemented in the postacquisition period by the benefits of the Flutter Edge. Our acquisitions of FanDuel, Adjarabet, Junglee Games, tombola and Sisal are examples of this strategy. We believe that there remains significant 125 ----- further M&A potential to add market-leading businesses in regulated markets where the Group does not currently have a presence. - **Returns to shareholders: We expect that the Group’s projected cash generation will permit us to reduce our leverage ratio over time and provide significant future balance sheet capacity. Although we do not currently have any specific plans to pay dividends or engage in significant share repurchases, once we have optimized our leverage, we intend to return to shareholders capital that cannot be effectively deployed through organic investment or value creative M&A. We had a net loss per share of $(6.89), $(2.44) and $(5.24) for the years ended December 31, 2023, 2022 and 2021, respectively. The combination of margin benefits, cashflow generation and disciplined capital allocation is expected to drive earnings per share growth and long-term value creation.

Our sportsbook offerings, such as FanDuel, Sportsbet or Sky Betting & Gaming, involve a customer placing a bet (wager) on various types of sporting events at fixed odds determined by us. Bets are made in advance of the sporting event that will determine the outcome of the wager. In the event the specified outcome occurs, the customer wins the bet and is paid out based upon the odds assigned at the time of the bet. We generate revenue by setting odds in a manner that includes a theoretical spread to be earned on each contest less winnings paid and expenses associated with promotional activity. In addition to this revenue, revenue from our real-money games (i.e., games in which real money is wagered on the outcome of the game) includes revenue earned on the processing of real-money deposits and cash-out options (which gives the customers the option to exit the game and to obtain an early return from their bet), in specific currencies, which is sometimes referred to as conversion margins.

We offer our customers peer-to-business (“P2B”) iGaming products, peer-to-peer (“P2P”) iGaming products and lottery products. Our P2B iGaming products involve customers betting against the house. Our iGaming products allow customers to bet on a range of games of chance such as online casino, bingo and machine gaming terminals. We provide a combination of third-party content and proprietary games, reflecting a shift to inhouse developed products in order to differentiate ourselves from our competitors. Our iGaming offerings typically include the full suite of games available in land-based casinos, such as blackjack, roulette and slot machines. We generate revenue through the gross bets placed less payouts on winning bets, which is also referred to as “hold.” Our P2P iGaming products include poker and rummy. As P2P operators, we are generally not exposed to the risks of game play or the outcome of the game, as we typically take a rake or commission from the game play. For P2P games, player liquidity, or the number or volume of players with an operator, 126 ----- is critical to the success of the game, with a greater number of players supporting a wider range and greater volume of games and larger tournaments, increasing the quality of the offering to the consumer. As a result, larger scale poker or rummy operations will benefit from superior player liquidity in their systems, which, in turn, improves their offering to customers, creating a positive feedback loop. We also offer our customers lottery products through our Sisal brand under fixed term licenses known as lottery concessions in various jurisdictions. For example, SuperEnalotto, Win for Life, VinciCasa, Eurojackpot and SiVincTutto operate in Italy, Sisal Sans operates in Turkey and Sisal Loterie Maroc operates in Morocco. Our lottery products involve customers purchasing a ticket where they have the potential to win a prize and where the winning outcome is drawn at random. Sisal receives a commission in respect of the lottery services provided under the concession agreement.

We include within other product revenue our P2P sports betting products, which involve customers playing/betting against each other and not against the house, where we make a commission on the bets. Our sports betting P2P products include the Betfair betting exchanges, DFS offered by FanDuel and Junglee Games and horse racing wagering offered under the TVG brand. We also offer business-to-business pricing and risk management services, where we earn revenues from providing these services to other businesses in our sector.

As of December 31, 2023, we offered our products in over 100 countries and had 12.3 million AMPs globally. See “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of _Operations—Key Operational Metrics” for additional information regarding how we calculate AMPs data,_ including a discussion regarding duplication of players that exists in such data. For the year ended December 31, 2023, our U.S. division constituted 38.0% of our revenue, our UKI division constituted 25.8% of our revenue, our Australian division constituted 12.3% of our revenue and our International division constituted 23.9% of our revenue.

Our U.S. division offers sports betting, casino, DFS and horse racing wagering products to players across various states in the United States, mainly online but with sports betting services also provided through a small number of retail outlets, and certain online products in the province of Ontario in Canada. The U.S. division is our fastest growing and our largest division, constituting $4,484 million (or 38.0%) of our revenue for the year ended December 31, 2023. For the three months ended December 31, 2023, we had a 43.2% share of the online sports betting market in the states where FanDuel sportsbook was live and a 25.7% share of the iGaming market in states where FanDuel casino and PokerStars (U.S.) were live. For 2023, the U.S. division consisted of the following brands: FanDuel, TVG and PokerStars (U.S.).
